headline: Sandwiches the Miami Way, at Pilar Cuban Bakery in Brooklyn
abstract: Homemade bread is just the starting act at this new Bedford-Stuyvesant spot.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiches, with all their permutations, are an invitation to overzealous tinkering. They can be stacked up toward heaven in multiple layers or stuffed with an entire Thanksgiving dinner. They can overflow with soupy meats and be eaten with a fork and knife. And then there was that time KFC used fried chicken instead of bread to do the hard work of containing sliced cheese and bacon. The risk is that a particularly kooky sandwich values shock over logic.

Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, to be part of a celebration at the White House of the team’s victory in the Super Bowl, ignoring concerns about Mr. Kraft’s recent  charges of soliciting prostitution.

headline: From Dresden on the 50th Anniversary of ‘Slaughterhouse-Five’
abstract: When Kurt Vonnegut was at work on his hugely influential antiwar novel, “he was writing to save his own life,” his daughter said.
lead_paragraph: DRESDEN, Germany — Last month, 74 years to the day since the bombers came, the late winter sky was gray as German tour guide Danilo Hommel called a halt before a short, dark green door in a large terracotta-roofed building that today forms part of an events and conference complex. One among several structures like it are laid out in neat rows in a bend of Germany’s River Elbe, two miles from Dresden’s historically reconstructed center.

headline: DNA Clues to an Ancient Canary Islands Voyage
keywords: ['Indigenous People', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: The islands’ pioneers likely arrived centuries before European conquest, as part of a large-scale movement of people from North Africa.
lead_paragraph: Today the Canary Islands are a tourist hub, a volcanic archipelago with palm trees and azure beaches, located off the coast of Morocco and governed by Spain. But the history of this paradise is marred by the brutal conquest, enslavement and treatment of its indigenous people by European colonizers beginning around the 15th century.

headline: New Zealand Took 6 Days to Plan New Gun Laws. Here’s How Other Countries Reacted to Shootings.

headline: Our Teen Houseguest Seems to Be Stealing Stuff
abstract: Should we confront her?
lead_paragraph: A teenage relative spends occasional weekends with us in the city, mostly to escape her sheltered life at home. She loves going to museums, shopping and even having dinner with us at our favorite diner. And we like having her. But the last two times she stayed over, we noticed objects of sentimental value were missing. The first time, we assumed we misplaced it. But after the second incident, we believe she took them. No one else had access to them. Should we say something?

headline: Indra Nooyi: ‘I’m Not Here to Tell You What to Eat’
abstract: In her conservative Brahmin family in India, education was everything. That prepared her to thrive in corporate America and rise to become chief executive of PepsiCo.
lead_paragraph: When Indra Nooyi stepped down as chief executive of PepsiCo last year, she was replaced by a man — and the ranks of female C.E.O.s further dwindled. Today, fewer than 5 percent of companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500 are led by women.

headline: A Lighter Matthew Barney Goes Back to School, and Back Home
abstract: The artist dances with wolves, and hunters, in his new film “Redoubt,” shot in his native Idaho. It’s the most emancipated work of his career.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Two parallel homecomings give shape to “Redoubt,” the much anticipated and unexpectedly nimble new project that Matthew Barney debuted here earlier this month. One is to Yale University, where Mr. Barney, class of 1989, began to merge ornery sculpture made with plastics and Vaseline with athletic performances and perplexing symbolism. Thirty years after graduating, the artist elected to present his newest project on the campus where he made his first mature work, in which the undergraduate would dangle from his studio walls or climb naked at Yale’s cathedral-like gym.

headline: Ichiro Suzuki Is Not Baseball’s Hit King. He Is So Much More.

headline: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Murder! Espionage! Fashion! We’ve got a fun grab-bag of books this week, from true crime (“The Trial of Lizzie Borden”) to memoir (Isaac Mizrahi’s “I.M.,” Aatish Taseer’s “The Twice-Born”) to three different takes on groundbreaking women: an anthology of Andrea Dworkin’s feminist writings, a group study of five female novelists and a biography of the woman who organized a spy ring for the French Resistance. In fiction, Helen Oyeyemi has a new novel, and we recommend story collections from David Means and Christos Ikonomou alongside a debut novel from Novuyo Rosa Tshuma that explores Zimbabwe’s troubled history. Finally, something from one of our own: The Times’s top newsroom lawyer, David McCraw, has written a spirited examination of truth, journalism and the First Amendment as it plays out in his job and in the culture at large. That book, “Truth in Our Times,” is a good bet for Times readers as much as Times employees, and for anyone who cares about the future of a free press.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the College Admissions Cheating Scandal

Dozens of wealthy parents paid millions of dollars in bribes. headline: How Anne Welsh McNulty, Philanthropist, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: When she’s not scouting the next generation of global leaders, Ms. McNulty likes to ride Citi Bikes with her boyfriend or peruse books at the Strand.
lead_paragraph: Anne Welsh McNulty, a former managing director at Goldman Sachs and now the chief executive of the McNulty Foundation, is focused on locating and nurturing the next generation of formidable leaders. In the last three years alone, she has given more than $18 million to organizations with that goal in mind, including creating the annual $100,000 McNulty Prize for individuals willing to address seemingly intractable problems. She’s also developing leadership programs for women at Villanova University and for men and women at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. Her imprint also can be found at schools like St. Joseph’s University and Hunter College, where she is cultivating female movers and shakers in math and science. Ms. McNulty lives in an apartment in Downtown Manhattan and spends as much time as she can with her three grown children.

abstract: At least 45 pro-government forces and 12 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
lead_paragraph: The deadliest attack took place in Faryab Province, where a Taliban Red Unit attacked a military base and security outposts in Arkalik village. At least 22 Afghan security forces were killed, eight police officers were wounded and four police officers were taken prisoner. The Taliban captured the military base and four outposts, looting all weapons and equipment. In Badghis Province, the Taliban carried out the biggest known capture of Afghan soldiers of the war, taking 150 prisoners after they chased units into neighboring Turkmenistan and that country forced them back, Afghan officials said on Sunday. The operation took place in Bala Murghab District in the northwestern Afghan province of Badghis. The Taliban later announced that they had released 58 soldiers who promised that they would not rejoin the Afghan security forces.

headline: Five Places to Visit in Minneapolis
abstract: The NCAA Final Four basketball tournament is in town, and the local chef Brenda Langton serves up five new spots in the Downtown East neighborhood just four blocks away.
lead_paragraph: From Downtown East in Minneapolis, it’s only a four-block walk to the U.S. Bank Stadium, the glass-sheathed building that opened in 2016 and is host of the NCAA Final Four basketball tournament from April 6 to 8. The neighborhood is seeing action of its own lately. Beautiful warehouses converted into condos, along with tasteful shops and restaurants, are filling in the once-industrial area. Brenda Langton, the chef and owner of the organic and locally focused Spoonriver restaurant and the founder of the Mill City Farmers Market, both in Downtown East, has seen it all. “It’s a very diverse neighborhood and people come from all over to walk the riverfront in the evening when the lights really make it shine,” she said. Ms. Langton, who was nominated for best restaurateur in 2019 by the James Beard Foundation, shares five new spots in the bustling area.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Mosques', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: This popular urban patch has been a symbol of the secular republic for nearly 100 years, but six years after deadly protests there, contentious changes have begun to alter its character in major ways.

headline: Why Baltimore Persists as a Cultural Beacon
abstract: The city (population 600,000) has produced an eclectic variety of artists, including John Waters, Joyce J. Scott, David Simon and Abdu Ali.
lead_paragraph: “HEY, WHERE THE [EXPLETIVE] are we anyway today?” asks one of the troupe members of Lady Divine’s Cavalcade of Perversions in the opening moments of John Waters’s raucously disgusting 1970 film “Multiple Maniacs.” The answer was the front lawn of Waters’s parents’ house in the Baltimore suburb of Lutherville, Md. Much of the film, like many in Waters’s oeuvre, spills out across the streets of Baltimore; the final sequence recalls the gleeful opening of “A Hard Day’s Night” (1964) turned on its head, with crowds of young people charging down city blocks in flight from the rampaging drag queen Divine. (Just before this, Divine is sexually assaulted by a giant lobster, one of the more disturbing non sequiturs in a film that consists of almost nothing but them.)

headline: Israel Is on the Brink of Disaster. Trump Just Made Things Worse.

lead_paragraph: On April 9, Israelis will go to the polls to choose their next government. The campaign has largely been a referendum on whether Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu should remain Israel’s leader in light of his expected indictment in three corruption cases for bribery and breach of trust. With those scandals front and center, policy disagreements have largely been ignored, leaving Israeli voters at risk of unwittingly bringing an avoidable disaster on themselves by annexing territory in the West Bank.

lead_paragraph: Mötley Crüe’s first gig, as dramatized in Jeff Tremaine’s Netflix adaptation of the band’s memoir, “The Dirt,” does not go well. The drummer, Tommy Lee, knocks over a cymbal before anyone plays a note; the crowd’s heckling turns into a full-on brawl. But when that fight is over, a guy in the back punctures the silence to scream, “[Expletive] yeah, Mötley Crüe!”

headline: Seeing Myself Through My Child’s Eyes
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life']

lead_paragraph: One night recently I got an unexpected glimpse of how my children see me. I noticed new pictures on my phone, and vaguely recalled that one of my 5-year-old twins had been playing with my phone while I was working on a local news article and attempting to feed the baby.

headline: An Election Not Quite as It Seems
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Constitution (US)', 'Royal Families', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The one in Thailand on Sunday will be less a vote of confidence in the military than a test for the monarchy.
lead_paragraph: KHON KAEN, Thailand — On a recent afternoon, the horse tracks of this small northeastern town had the looks of an impromptu music concert for mostly older women, with large crowds packed around a makeshift stage near what seemed to be an unused racing lane. By my count, some 15,000 locals, many of them farmers with weathered skin, had gathered there for a rally of the Pheu Thai party, which calls for better health care, a higher minimum wage and subsidized agriculture prices. An heir to populist parties led by two former prime ministers who were deposed — Thaksin Shinawatra and his sister Yingluck — Pheu Thai is said to be the front-runner in Sunday’s general election, the first since the military coup of 2014.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Day 2: Duke, Virginia and U.N.C. Stumble, Then Stroll
abstract: Live scores, updates and analysis from Day 2 of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: Duke, Virginia and North Carolina — three No. 1 seeds from the Atlantic Coast Conference — opened the N.C.A.A. tournament with victories on Friday, but not before each one survived a scare.

headline: For Urinary Incontinence, Try Behavioral Treatments or Drugs, or Both
abstract: Bladder training, biofeedback and other behavioral therapies may work even better in combination with drugs.
lead_paragraph: Both behavioral and drug treatments can be effective in treating women for urinary incontinence, researchers report in the Annals of Internal Medicine, and they may work even better in combination.

headline: Trump Has Liberated Israel
abstract: The president’s announcement on the Golan Heights will finally free us from the “land for peace” formula that none of us believe in anyway.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — On Thursday evening here in Israel, after President Trump announced that “it is time for the United States to fully recognize Israel’s sovereignty over the Golan Heights” and our prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, thanked the president for his “historic” decision, I wanted to talk to someone I trusted on the issue, someone with perspective. So I contacted Zvi Hauser.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin, the Best on Skis, Gets Used to Putting a Sport on Her Shoulders
abstract: After setting a host of World Cup records, Shiffrin is taking on the task of replacing Lindsey Vonn as the face of American skiing.
lead_paragraph: It is Wednesday evening at rush hour and Mikaela Shiffrin, perhaps the most dominant athlete in the world, strolled unobserved through a crowded Central Park.

headline: Sun Bears Mimic Each Other’s Faces. Scientists Didn’t Expect That.
abstract: They are solitary mammals, but like primates and people, they seem to be able to read one another’s facial expressions.
lead_paragraph: The sun bears were making faces at each other. And that was a bit of a surprise.

headline: Italy Gives Xi, and China’s Vast Infrastructure Project, a Royal Welcome
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Foreign Investments', 'International Relations']
abstract: Italy would become the first Group of 7 nation to officially join China’s vast One Belt One Road project on Saturday, a sign of Beijing’s growing influence.
lead_paragraph: ROME — President Xi Jinping of China arrived on Friday at Rome’s presidential palace with a cavalry escort usually reserved for royals. For a three-day visit, Italy pulled out all the stops for an economic superpower promising billions in investment and trade deals in exchange for officially signing on to China’s vast new Silk Road.

headline: Suspect in Utrecht Tram Shooting Confessed, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The man, who faces terrorism charges in the Netherlands, made the admission in his first court hearing and told the judge that he had acted alone, according to Dutch prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: The primary suspect in the shooting aboard a Dutch tram that left three people dead and five wounded confessed on Friday to the attack, and said that he acted alone, prosecutors said.

headline: The Teddy Bear Test, and Other Ways to Pass a State Tax Audit
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Tax Evasion', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'States (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Income', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Wealthy people with multiple homes may try to establish residency in lower-tax states to reduce their bill. Advisers say it’s a complicated task.
lead_paragraph: Every year around this time, people grumble about their tax bills. This year, taxpayers who lost the deduction for state and local taxes in the 2017 tax overhaul bill — mainly those in California and states in the Northeast — are going to grumble even more. And for some, that grousing has turned to talk of fleeing to lower-tax states.

headline: Guilt, Jealousy, Empathy: Your Dog Has the Same Emotions You Do
abstract: Frans de Waal’s new book, “Mama’s Last Hug: Animal Emotions and What They Tell Us About Ourselves,” debuts on the best-seller list this week at No. 4.
lead_paragraph: Have you watched the heartbreaking viral video of Mama, a dying elderly chimpanzee, as she says goodbye to a scientist who was part of her life for many years? (If you haven’t seen it, you should — just lay in a supply of Kleenex first.) The Dutch-born primatologist Frans de Waal believes that Mama’s tender caresses show that animal emotions are the same as our own.

lead_paragraph: The authorities in Charlottesville, Va., arrested a 17-year-old boy on Friday in connection with an online threat targeting black and Hispanic students, bringing a sense of relief to a saga that had forced the closing of the city’s public schools for two straight days.

headline: A Ragoût to Remember
abstract: Made entirely of spring vegetables and served with lemony couscous, this ragoût is a most satisfying vegetarian supper.
lead_paragraph: Is “ragoût” just a five-dollar word for stew, or is there a difference? To me, the French word sounds more elegant and painstaking. (To be clear, we’re not talking about ragù, an Italian pasta sauce.) And though a ragoût can take many forms, one made entirely of vegetables is something quite special.

headline: Rewatching ‘Game of Thrones,’ Season 4: Lannister Stumbles
abstract: Champions and negligent rulers, reader questions over Targaryen lineage and more in our look back at the fourth season.
lead_paragraph: The final season of “Game of Thrones” arrives April 14. Before then, we’re getting prepared by rewatching the first seven seasons. Sign up to get these straight to your inbox.

headline: G.M. Plans New Electric Vehicle Made at Chevy Bolt Plant
abstract: The carmaker said it would invest $300 million in its Orion Township, Mich., plant in connection with producing the new model there.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is moving to widen its lineup of electric cars, and adding jobs in the process.

headline: In Praise of Sauce
abstract: A life without sauce is not one fully lived: Here are five saucy recipes for your week.
lead_paragraph: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. By now have we all read this amazing article on “snowplow parenting”? It’s about parents who go to sometimes-extreme lengths to remove obstacles from their kids’ lives. The part I can’t get over is about a girl who didn’t like sauce: “Her whole life, her parents had helped her avoid sauce, calling friends before going to their houses for dinner. At college, she didn’t know how to cope with the cafeteria options — covered in sauce.”

headline: A Supposed Stickler for the Rules, Now at the Center of a U.S.C. Scandal
keywords: ['College Admissions Scandal (2019)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'College Athletics']
abstract: At U.S.C., Donna Heinel was known as the athletic administrator who clashed with coaches over prospective recruits. Then she got indicted.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ron Allice, the track and field coach at the University of Southern California, assumed bad news was on the way when Donna Heinel summoned him to her office back in 2011.

headline: A Bite-Size Square of Canada’s History, Culture and Craving
abstract: How the Nanaimo bar, a three-layer no-bake treat from British Columbia, conquered a nation’s palate.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian city of Nanaimo, in British Columbia, has been a scrappy outpost of the Hudson’s Bay Company, a coal mining center and a timber town. But its place in history may be forever entwined with its culinary namesake, one of the world’s sweetest treats.

headline: An Alzheimer’s Drug Trial Gave Me Hope, and Then It Ended
abstract: I was a small piece in the search to find a cure. Now I feel as if I’m getting erased, and medical science doesn’t have any answers.
lead_paragraph: I knew that participating in a clinical trial for an Alzheimer’s drug was unlikely to help me. But it gave me hope.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Discovery’ Season 2, Episode 10: Just Breathe
abstract: In this week’s “Star Trek: Discovery,” everything happens. There were so many plot twists to keep track of that the audience might need time travel of its own just to keep up.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 10: ‘The Red Angel’

headline: Can We Get Better at Forgetting?
abstract: Some things aren’t worth remembering. Science is slowly working out how we might let that stuff go.
lead_paragraph: Whatever its other properties, memory is a reliable troublemaker, especially when navigating its stockpile of embarrassments and moral stumbles. Ten minutes into an important job interview and here come screenshots from a past disaster: the spilled latte, the painful attempt at humor. Two dates into a warming relationship and up come flashbacks of an earlier, abusive partner.

headline: Adapted, Adjusted, but Always (Kind of) Paella
abstract: It’s baked in a roasting pan and full of chiles and chorizo, but Yotam Ottolenghi hopes his take on the Spanish classic will join a proud tradition of adaptations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Every dish has a story to tell, but that story often isn’t what you expect or, indeed, want it to be.

headline: Brexit Deal is Still Unacceptable, Key Government Ally Says
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The Democratic Unionist Party of Northern Ireland strongly suggested that it would oppose Prime Minister Theresa May’s plan, damaging her hopes for its approval in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A small but influential party aligned with Prime Minister Theresa May’s government suggested on Friday that it still cannot support her plan for Britain’s departure from the European Union, a development that could doom her hopes of persuading Parliament to pass the deal next week on the third try.

headline: An Elusive Whale Is Found All Around the World
abstract: Researchers are learning about a newly identified species of baleen whales, tracing sightings and sounds to learn that they stay mainly in tropical waters.
lead_paragraph: Salvatore Cerchio stunned the small world of whale science in 2015 when he found examples of a new species in the wild for the first time. Now, he’s mapped the habitat of that species, called Omura’s whale after Hideo Omura, a prominent Japanese whale biologist.

headline: Trump Taps Fed Critic Stephen Moore for Board Seat
abstract: If formally nominated and confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Moore, a Heritage Foundation economist, would push for the central bank to cut interest rates to increase growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday that he had offered a position on the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors to Stephen Moore, a conservative economic adviser who has become an outspoken critic of the Fed’s interest rate policy.

headline: Looking Back at ‘A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius’
abstract: In his 2000 memoir, “A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius,” Dave Eggers becomes the steward of his brother after their parents die within weeks of each other.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s issue, Idra Novey reviews Dave Eggers’s “The Parade.” In 2000, Michiko Kakutani wrote in The Times about Eggers’s first book, “A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius.”

headline: An Artist on Finding Balance, and His Giant Basketball Sculpture
abstract: Ahead of two major shows, the painter Jonas Wood reflects on his early career — and the most unusual object in his studio.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Wood’s East Hollywood studio — a refurbished industrial space hidden behind a razor-wired metal gate — is populated with the familiar objects that appear in his paintings. There are colonies of potted plants and basketball paraphernalia that ranges in size from plush couch cushions to man-sized orbs. Every room is filled with art, most notably by the ceramist Shio Kusaka, Wood’s studio mate and wife, and Kiki and Momo, their son and daughter.

headline: The Genoa Bridge Collapse
abstract: The company that runs Italy’s highways says, “Our focus will continue to be assisting people affected by the disaster and cooperating with the investigations.”

headline: From Jay Gatsby to Kunta Kinte
abstract: The legendary graphic designer, Seymour Chwast, draws some of his favorite protagonists.

headline: Don’t Call St. Nicholas Hockey Club a ‘Beer League’ Team
abstract: Formed in 1896, St. Nick’s was one of the nation’s first amateur hockey clubs. It lives on, Saturday afternoons at Chelsea Piers.
lead_paragraph: An amateur men’s hockey club claims the ice at Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan at 4 p.m. each Saturday during the fall, winter and spring for a brisk 80-minute scrimmage, with the skaters divided into two teams, and no officials, face-offs or heavy checking.

headline: Graphic Novels That Will Diagnose Your Disease
abstract: In her latest Graphic Content column, Hillary Chute looks at the genre of “graphic medicine,” comics illustrating the challenges of doctors and travails of patients.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ian Williams, a Welsh-born physician, started publishing comics under a pseudonym in 2007, the year he began a website devoted to so-called graphic medicine. Currently located in Brighton, Williams is now one of the primary creators of what has become a rich field combining comics and health care, broadly conceived. A group of artists, academics and medical professionals now maintain a resource-rich version of the website (graphicmedicine.org), sponsor an annual international conference and oversee a book series. In 2015 they issued the “Graphic Medicine Manifesto,” a part-prose, part-comics title this paper reviewed favorably. Williams, one of the manifesto’s authors, is now out with his second book of graphic fiction, THE LADY DOCTOR (Penn State University, $24.95), which, like his first, “The Bad Doctor,” is set in a small town in Wales and offers the engrossing perspective of a hard-working and fallible physician. Lois Pritchard, 40, single and a secret smoker, wears a sharp black bob and pointy high-heeled boots. A general practitioner, she also works part time at the local Genitourinary Medicine clinic, treating various problems of genital and urinary origins that the book selectively illustrates, including numerous S.T.D.s (“muck in the fuel pipe,” as one man puts it).

headline: Antonia Rey, Latin Actress of Stage and Screen, Dies at 92
abstract: She and her husband fled Cuba under Castro, giving up their prominence in theater there. In the North, she had a steady diet of ethnic roles.
lead_paragraph: In her native Cuba in the 1950s, Antonia Rey was a leading lady of the stage, playing Madge in William Inge’s “Picnic,” the title character in George Bernard Shaw’s “Candida” and Elizabeth Proctor in Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible.”

headline: A Kushner Is an N.B.A. Owner
abstract: Joshua Kushner, whose older brother is the son-in-law of President Trump, bought a minority stake in the Memphis Grizzlies earlier this season. Top N.B.A. players have spoken out against Trump.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Kushner, the venture capitalist whose older brother is President Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, became a minority shareholder of the N.B.A.’s Memphis Grizzlies earlier this season, according to four people familiar with the matter.

headline: What’s Going On Between Canada and China? Our Experts Share Their Thoughts.
abstract: The Times gathered four correspondents and an editor to discuss the currently fraught relations between the two nations.
lead_paragraph: We continued following the political turmoil in Ottawa  this week. But we also held a special event for subscribers on another matter of national importance: Canada’s relationship with China.

keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Arab-Israeli War (1948)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump undercut his own Treasury Department on Friday with a sudden announcement that he had rolled back newly imposed North Korea sanctions, appearing to overrule national security experts as a favor to Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader.

headline: Indiana Teachers Were Shot With Pellets During Active-Shooter Drill, Union Says
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Organized Labor', 'Education (K-12)']

headline: Stocks Fall as Bond Market Flashes a Recession Warning
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: When long-term interest rates fall below short-term rates, it’s called a yield curve inversion. It’s one of Wall Street’s favored predictors of a recession, and it happened on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The bond market smells a recession. On Friday, stock investors caught a whiff, too.

headline: Review: A Baritone Ends His Residency With a Poetic Homage
abstract: Matthias Goerne performs a distinctively American John Adams piece to end his adventurous artist-in-residence series with the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: Some artists, even acclaimed ones, use a residency with a major orchestra to perform the works they are known for. Bolder artists seize these coveted opportunities to take chances and work closely with individual musicians in the orchestra, as the superb German baritone Matthias Goerne has done this season with the New York Philharmonic.

headline: The Playlist: Tame Impala Evolves, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Lizzo and Missy Elliott, Ibibio Sound Machine, the Last Poets and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Robert Kraft’s Future in the Balance: ‘I Am Truly Sorry’
abstract: Tom Brady, Meek Mill, Drew Bledsoe and Kenny Chesney on the man caught up in a scandal.
lead_paragraph: When you find yourself at 77 a billionaire six times over and an N.F.L. team owner practically running out of fingers for Super Bowl rings, there aren’t a ton of opportunities you haven’t already enjoyed. Private jets are your subways. Weekends with pals at $2,000-a-night island resorts are your backyard barbecues. The question “what to do for kicks?” becomes harder to answer.

headline: Trump Administration Strikes Tougher Stance Ahead of China Talks
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: The United States is channeling a tougher approach as Trump’s negotiators head to China this weekend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said the United States would keep tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese goods in place even if the two sides reached a trade deal, channeling a tougher approach as his negotiators head to Beijing this weekend for a crucial round of talks.

headline: Batman Is Turning 80. Fighting Crime Must Pay.
abstract: The hero’s journey to this milestone is filled with many memorable moments, from his debut, to Robin’s and Batgirl’s and more.
lead_paragraph: Holy milestones, Batman! Detective Comics, where the caped crusader debuted on March 30, 1939, will reach issue No. 1000 on Wednesday, just days before the hero’s 80th birthday. “It is evidence of the greatness and power of the Batman concept that the character has appeared continuously over eight decades,” Peter Sanderson, a comic book historian, said.

headline: Trump and Conscience in the Age of Demagogues
abstract: What a brave Jew at a Nazi rally in New York tells us about our times.
lead_paragraph: His name is Isadore Greenbaum. He’s a Jew, a plumber’s helper from Brooklyn. He rushes onto the stage, beneath a portrait of George Washington flanked by swastikas. He tries to accost the Nazi who is denouncing the “Jewish-controlled press” and calling for a “white gentile-ruled” United States. Uniformed storm troopers beat him. Police officers drag him from the stage, pants ripped, arms raised in desperate entreaty. The mob howls in delight.

headline: What Makes a Catastrophic Flood? And Is Climate Change Causing More of Them?
abstract: Floods are complicated. But here are simple answers to questions about flooding, climate change and staying safe when the water rises.
lead_paragraph: With floods submerging expanses of the Midwest and government scientists warning that this spring could bring a historic flood season in the United States, it’s natural to ask why it is happening. What causes catastrophic flooding? And what is the role of climate change?

headline: Anita Silvers, an Authority on Disability Rights, Dies at 78
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Disabilities', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Philosophy']
abstract: A well-regarded philosophy professor, Dr. Silvers knew the subject firsthand, having had polio as a child.
lead_paragraph: Anita Silvers, a philosophy professor who was a leading voice in the interpretation of the Americans With Disabilities Act, arguing that disability rights should be viewed the same as other civil rights and not as an accommodation or as a social safety net issue, died on March 14 in San Francisco. She was 78.

headline: T Suggests: Gingham Handbags, a Shrine to Italian Design and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: Each time I visit my parents’ house, I find myself mining the drawers of my childhood dresser for gems from the early aughts. Many of these items were bat mitzvah gifts — precious handbags, dainty pearl earrings — the kind of appropriate, just-so pieces that a 13-year-old could conceivably wear but that were more likely gifted with the future in mind. Coming of Age, the designer Amanda Lurie’s elegant and playfully nostalgic new line of accessories, reminds me of these beloved pieces.

abstract: A British family’s 11th-century, 20-bedroom castle and vineyard in southern Tuscany.
lead_paragraph: A British family’s 11th-century, 20-bedroom castle and vineyard in southern Tuscany.

abstract: Inside the dilapidated fortress in the Italian countryside revitalized by Charlotte Horton and her family.

headline: T’s Design Issue: In Context
abstract: As long as there are humans, there will be art — and nothing will ever stop us from trying to make our lives more beautiful.
lead_paragraph: Architecture is, by its nature, an imposition. It’s other things as well, of course: At its most basic, it offers shelter; at its best, it offers provocation, an invitation to marvel at what the imagination can conjure and engineering can accomplish.

headline: Pinterest Is Rare ‘Unicorn’ Preparing an I.P.O. Without Hemorrhaging Cash
abstract: The start-up, which lets people create virtual “pin boards,” officially joined the herd of tech companies stampeding to the public markets this year by unveiling its offering prospectus.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest is preparing for its debut on Wall Street with a claim that few other “unicorn” start-ups can make: It is not a financial sinkhole.

headline: Reviving a Centuries-Old Abandoned Castle and, With It, a Way of Life
abstract: In southern Tuscany, a family of British bohemians has created an elegantly undone cultural refuge that pays homage to the everyday life of ancient Italy.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE HORTON FIRST learned of Castello di Potentino, the dilapidated fortress that is now her world, from a guidebook more than two decades ago. Perched on a promontory jutting from the face of Mount Amiata, a volcanic peak in southern Tuscany with a purplish-blue cast, the 20-bedroom castle, thought to have been built on Etruscan foundations dating to the fourth century B.C., was all that remained of an 11th-century bulwark with medieval walls encircling a central stone-paved courtyard. Such a mythic site was a siren song to Horton and her family members, a bohemian tribe reminiscent of the British expatriates in Italy gently teased by E.M. Forster in “A Room With a View”: intrepid, culturally voracious and joyously out of bounds.

headline: 900 Voices From Gen Z, America’s Most Diverse Generation
abstract: What is it like to be part of the group that has been called the most diverse generation in U.S. history? We asked members of Generation Z to tell us what makes them different from their friends, and to describe their identity. Here's what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: What is it like to be part of the group that has been called the most diverse generation in U.S. history? We asked members of Generation Z to tell us what makes them different from their friends, and to describe their identity. Here's what they had to say.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, on Friday delivered a report on his inquiry into Russian interference in the 2016 election to Attorney General William P. Barr, bringing to a close an investigation that has consumed the nation and cast a shadow over President Trump for nearly two years.

headline: Will the Mueller Report Be Made Public? Answers to 6 Key Questions
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Executive Privilege, Doctrine of']
abstract: Many hoped the special counsel report would provide answers about the Trump campaign and Russia. But they aren’t forthcoming yet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long-awaited special counsel report is complete, 675 days after Robert S. Mueller III was named to oversee the investigation into Russia’s election interference, whether  any Trump associates coordinated with that plot and whether President Trump tried to obstruct justice. Attorney General William P. Barr has the document and notified lawmakers. But it has yet to be made public, and the path to its potential release — or the release of the facts it contains — is complicated.

headline: A Children’s Book Is Causing a Political Scandal in Baltimore. It’s Quite a Tale.

abstract: Once upon a time, Catherine Pugh, now Baltimore’s mayor, struck a $500,000 deal to sell her “Healthy Holly” books to a hospital provider, while sitting on its board.
lead_paragraph: What has become a full-blown political scandal in Baltimore started innocently enough. In fact, it began with a children’s book.

headline: Russia, Trump and Mueller: The Major Moments in the Case
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The sprawling Russia story, explained.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The report on the investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, will be made public on Thursday, and unless you’re a counterintelligence analyst, you may have lost track of how we got to this point in the saga and what Mr. Mueller was investigating in the first place. Here is a guide to what has happened over the past three years (yes, it’s been that long) and what we learned.

headline: How the Mueller Investigation Unfolded

When I complain about the water, management says they’ll send an engineer to look, but nothing improves. Other residents have experienced similar issues. headline: Medicare for All Would Abolish Private Insurance. ‘There’s No Precedent in American History.’
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'your-feed-science']
abstract: Unlike Obamacare, emerging plans would sweep away the private health insurance system. What would that mean for the companies’ workers, the stock market and the cost of care?
lead_paragraph: At the heart of the “Medicare for all” proposals championed by Senator Bernie Sanders and many Democrats is a revolutionary idea: Abolish private health insurance.

headline: Drug Prices on TV? They May Be Coming.
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Trump administration has drafted a rule that would require drug makers to disclose their prices in television ads, but the industry fears sticker shock and is fighting back.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is moving ahead with its proposal to require drug companies to disclose the often sky-high prices of their products in television commercials, despite strenuous objections and the threat of legal challenges by drug makers and TV broadcasters.

headline: Defying Allies, Italy Signs On to New Silk Road With China
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: The move by Italy to join China’s “One Belt One Road” project crystallized shifting geopolitical balances and the populist Italian government’s willingness to break with its traditional partners.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy resisted the entreaties and warnings of its European Union and American allies on Saturday by officially joining China’s vast new Silk Road at a signing ceremony with President Xi Jinping of China, a move that crystallized shifting geopolitical balances and the populist Italian government’s willingness to break with its traditional partners.

headline: The Islamic State Has Not Been Defeated
abstract: Make no mistake: The group will be back unless the conditions that gave birth to it are addressed.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State’s territorial rule has ended. On Saturday, the Syrian Democratic Forces, a United States-backed group, announced that the final sliver of territory under the jihadist group’s control had fallen.

headline: Israel Lobby Convenes in Washington Amid Fraying Bipartisanship and Rising Tension
keywords: ['Elections', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Palestinians', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: On the surface, the annual Aipac conference looks relatively unchanged. But recent actions by President Trump and rising criticism of Israel on the left are taking a toll.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 18,000 activists will converge in Washington on Sunday for the annual conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, as Democrats wrestle with the left’s rising criticism of Israel and as President Trump seeks to divide his political rivals while bolstering Israel’s embattled leader.

headline: After a Deadly Ferry Accident, a Grim Vigil at an Iraqi Morgue
abstract: At least 97 people have died in the accident, which turned a festive Kurdish New Year celebration this week into a scene of horror.
lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq — The drawn men waited silently outside the morgue on Saturday for the scream of an approaching ambulance carrying another victim of the devastating raft accident on the Tigris River this past week.

headline: ‘I Can’t Be Myself Here’: At the Border, Transgender Women Navigate 2 Worlds
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: For many transgender women, crossing between the United States and Mexico can also mean moving uncomfortably between genders.
lead_paragraph: MEXICALI, Mexico — In the pictures, Jess Enriquez Taylor wears artful makeup and her hair is carefully styled. But her face was bare as she rode the bus toward the international border one recent afternoon, and her long black hair was tucked under a hat.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop leads a many-legged expedition.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — “Split Decisions” is a much different mental test than we’re used to when solving word games, and it’s not usually one of the variety puzzles that I look forward to. Today’s was quite fun, though, and I’ve softened a bit — there were several really interesting convergences and a couple of mini-themes that I deduced, in a satisfying way, and enjoyed.

headline: Stephen Moore Would Be a Loyalist, not an Expert, at the Fed
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President Trump has tried to get the Federal Reserve to share his love of low interest rates. Now he’s ratcheting up the pressure.
lead_paragraph: President Trump, who craves low interest rates, has tried to bend the Federal Reserve to his will by tweeting insults and offering unsolicited advice. He threatened to fire Chairman Jerome H. Powell. He invited Mr. Powell to dinner. None of it worked as well as he would like. In the president’s view, high interest rates still are smothering economic growth.

headline: Jose Del Real on the Emotional Weight and ‘Thematic Whiplash’ of Covering California
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'News and News Media', 'Careers and Professions', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Jose Del Real has covered some of California’s most significant stories. One way he deals with the stress? Solo morning dance parties.
lead_paragraph: The Reader Center has started a new series of short interviews, Behind the Byline, to introduce you to Times journalists. Is there a reporter, photographer or editor whom you would like to get to know? Tell us in the form below.

headline: After Deadly Insider Attack, U.S. Airstrikes Kill 14 Civilians, Afghans Say
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: American and Afghan forces traded fire, provoked by a Taliban insider. Then, Afghan officials say, an American airstrike hit the home of a large refugee family.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — After the second firefight in the past 10 days between American soldiers and their Afghan allies, at least 14 civilians, most of them women and children, were killed in an airstrike on Saturday in northern Kunduz province, according to Afghan officials. At least four Afghan soldiers were also killed.

headline: 42 Years of Friendship
abstract: Pencils are sharp, solvers are ready and Will Shortz opens another American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, CONN. —  The first thing you notice is the hugging. There is a lot of hugging at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, something that you wouldn’t see at many other annual competitions. You probably wouldn’t see it among, say, competing Super Bowl teams.

headline: Discovered After 70, Black Artists Find Success, Too, Has Its Price
abstract: Once on the margins, older African-American artists are suddenly a hot commodity. They are relishing the attention while dealing with the market’s grueling demands.
lead_paragraph: McArthur Binion had been creating art almost completely under the radar for four decades, handling his own occasional sales and raising two children in Chicago on a teaching salary.

headline: Boeing Was ‘Go, Go, Go’ to Beat Airbus With the 737 Max
keywords: ['Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Pilots']
abstract: Caught short by its rival’s gains, Boeing raced to update its workhorse jet rather than design a new one. Workers describe a hectic project, but say they hadn’t felt safety was compromised.
lead_paragraph: Boeing faced an unthinkable defection in the spring of 2011. American Airlines, an exclusive Boeing customer for more than a decade, was ready to place an order for hundreds of new, fuel-efficient jets from the world’s other major aircraft manufacturer, Airbus.

headline: How College Changed My Life
abstract: We asked readers to discuss how the people they met and classes they took influenced them, and how much going to an elite school matters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Wi-Fi on Planes? A ‘Disaster,’ Says Bernard-Henri Lévy.
abstract: For a new one-man show, the French philosopher is traveling to 22 European cities this year. All he needs are books, white shirts and his current manuscript. No internet, please.
lead_paragraph: The philosopher Bernard-Henri Lévy has been a fixture on French television screens for decades. His commentary has been mocked, criticized, supported and lauded. Whether in writing, performing or speaking, he has no intention of slowing down.

headline: Attorney General Prepares to Brief Lawmakers and Trump on Report
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: Attorney General William P. Barr was determining what parts of the special counsel’s report to make public after a 22-month investigation into Russia’s effort to interfere in the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr and his team on Saturday pored over the highly anticipated report by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, a senior Justice Department official said, preparing to deliver the investigation’s “principal conclusions” to jittery lawmakers and President Trump as soon as Sunday.

headline: Auburn’s Bruce Pearl: A Coach With Plenty of Ability, Flair and Baggage
abstract: Pearl has made the Tigers into winners, but he was fired by Tennessee in 2011 for lying to the N.C.A.A., and two of his assistants have been sidelined by investigations in the last 17 months.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Auburn Coach Bruce Pearl would prefer that his players get the attention. That people write about and read about their improved graduation rates, about the good they have done in the community, about the wins they have piled up, even in this tumultuous season.

headline: N.C.A.A. Appeals Latest Antitrust Ruling
abstract: The ruling this month cleared a path for some athletes to receive more compensation than they do now, but limited it to expenses “related to education.”
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. said on Saturday that it was appealing a Federal District Court’s decision this month that barring athletes from being paid beyond a scholarship and related costs violated antitrust law.

headline: Jordan Peele’s ‘Us’ Is a New Kind of Superhero Movie
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Movies', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: Its superpower is letting black people just be themselves.
lead_paragraph: “Black Panther,” which made more than $1.3 billion last year, became one of the highest-grossing superhero movies of all time. It did that by delivering a wide-screen vision of Black Excellence, where blackness isn’t just about the generational trauma and pain that comes from living under racism. It’s about reckoning with choices made to hold on to one’s culture and the best way to carry it into the future.

headline: Turning 40 and Looking Death in the Eye
abstract: I used to think everything worked out for the best. But then my wife got cancer.
lead_paragraph: I’m turning 40 this week, and I’m still not sure what to do about it. Originally, I wanted to have a big party, a bacchanalian blowout to celebrate the official end of my youth. But then I thought better of the idea. What I really wanted was a childless weekend with my wife away in the Napa Valley. Even one night would be enough, so long as there was time for a soak, a meal, maybe a massage.

headline: Stop Calling Asian Women Adorable
abstract: When I'm at work I want to talk about work. Not my hair or skin.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible for me to catalog all the times I’ve been in a professional setting when someone thought it appropriate to tell me about my appearance.

headline: This Friendship Has Been Digitized
abstract: Do I need to explain to my son that a bot will never have his back?
lead_paragraph: “I’ll be there in a few minutes,” my 15-year-old son shouted from his room. “I’m playing Xbox with a friend.”

headline: A Case for the Electoral College
keywords: ['Electoral College', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: And why and how that case might fail.
lead_paragraph: Debates about the Electoral College, like the one that Democrats have lately instigated, often get bogged down in disputes about the intentions of the founding generation — whether they were trying to check mob rule, prop up Southern power, preserve the power of small states, or simply come to a necessarily arbitrary constitutional compromise.

headline: The First Time Women Shouted Their Abortions
abstract: Fifty years ago, a group of women stood up in a church and talked about ending their pregnancies. The way they did so still shapes how we discuss the topic today.
lead_paragraph: You couldn’t just casually threaten suicide — you had to sound like you meant it, the woman onstage recalled. “You have to go and bring a razor, or whatever: ‘If you don’t tell me I’m going to have an abortion right now, I’m going to go out and jump off the Verrazzano Bridge.’”

headline: Human Contact Is Now a Luxury Good
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Computer Monitors', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Science and Technology', 'Poverty']
abstract: Screens used to be for the elite. Now avoiding them is a status symbol.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Bill Langlois has a new best friend. She is a cat named Sox. She lives on a tablet, and she makes him so happy that when he talks about her arrival in his life, he begins to cry.

headline: A Pied-à-Terre Tax Will Bring Revenue New York Needs
keywords: ['Property Taxes', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Income Tax', 'State Legislatures', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: A tax on second homes of over $5 million won’t solve income inequality, but it could help boost the city’s coffers.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, the hedge fund magnate Kenneth C. Griffin paid a record-breaking $238 million for a penthouse on Central Park South, and it wasn’t even what most people would call home. Mr. Griffin is from Chicago, where he can put his feet up in a penthouse he bought for $59 million, or in one of the rooms on two floors he bought for $30 million in a hotel there. He also has a $60 million Miami condominium and a $122 million London mansion.

headline: Britain Is Drowning Itself in Nostalgia
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'Referendums', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Brexit has exposed my country as a solipsistic backwater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Recently, in the comforting gloom of a half-empty cinema, I found myself subjected to an advertisement for the country in which I live. A series of Britain’s cultural and sporting great and good, interspersed with “normal” people, rode in taxis, strode through the airport and squeezed themselves into economy class. “Dear Britain,” they said, taking turns with the lines while stowing their luggage and settling into their seats. “Dear old Britain. We love you … The way you pick yourself up when things get tough … How you follow your own path … How you tell it like it is (politely, of course!) … You’ve led revolutions of all kinds, yet you won’t shout about it, it’s just not in your nature. Instead, you’ll quietly make history.” At the end, cozily occupying the sweet spot between the roundly unifying and the vapidly uncontroversial, Olivia Colman, who recently won an Oscar for playing Queen Anne, said something about tea.

headline: Forget Self-Driving Cars. Bring Back the Stick Shift.
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)']
abstract: Technology meant to save us from distraction is making us less attentive.
lead_paragraph: I was backing my wife’s car out of our driveway when I realized I wasn’t watching the backup camera, nor was I looking out of the rear window. I was only listening for those “audible proximity alerts” — the high-pitched beeps that my car emits as I approach an object while in reverse. The problem was that my wife’s car, an older model, doesn’t offer such beeps.

headline: Our Chess Champion Has a Home
abstract: The 8-year-old refugee who last week was thrilled to have a trophy suddenly has so much more.
lead_paragraph: Tanitoluwa Adewumi, age 8, skidded around the empty apartment, laughing excitedly, then leapt onto his dad’s back. “I have a home!” he said in wonderment. “I have a home!”

headline: How Powerful Is Vladimir Putin Really?
abstract: Russia today doesn’t seem like “a properly run dictatorship.”
lead_paragraph: ORYOL, Russia — After 19 months in a Russian jail awaiting trial for “extremism,” Dennis O. Christensen, a Jehovah’s Witness from Denmark detained for his faith, received an unexpected lift from President Vladimir V. Putin at the end of last year.

headline: Open Thread: Let’s Talk About Who Will Be Designer of the Year
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'your-feed-fashion']
abstract: Yes, it’s CFDA time! Also, a designer who is no longer with us, but whose name everyone should know.
lead_paragraph: Hello and happy spring. Wednesday was its official start, though whether that means anything anymore given the state of the world’s weather is unclear.

headline: Man Charged in Subway Attack on 78-Year-Old Woman That Was Caught on Video, Police Say
abstract: The attack, on board a No. 2 train in the Bronx this month, was captured on a video that has gained more than 10 million views.

headline: At Democratic Campaign Events, Mueller Report Is Barely Mentioned
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']
abstract: The special counsel’s report, delivered on Friday, was on voters’ minds. But so were health care, immigration, school shootings and other subjects that hit closer to home.
lead_paragraph: RYE, N.H. — For Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday, it wasn’t quite campaigning as usual after the delivery of a long-awaited report from the special counsel roiled Washington over the weekend. But it was pretty close.

headline: Robert Kraft Apologizes in First Public Comments About Prostitution Case
abstract: The owner of the New England Patriots said in a statement that he was “truly sorry” for the “hurt and disappointment” he had caused.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since he was charged last month with two counts of soliciting prostitution in Jupiter, Fla., Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, commented publicly on the matter, apologizing in vague terms.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Day 3: Kentucky and L.S.U. Head to Round of 16
abstract: Louisiana State beat Maryland on a last-second shot, and Kentucky handed Wofford its first loss in 22 games. Ja Morant scored 28 in Murray State’s loss, and Villanova, the defending champion, fell.
lead_paragraph: One of the oldest adages about college basketball is that guard play is the key to tournament success. Amid the intensity and mayhem that unfold each March, it is often the most composed, savvy and talented guards who determine the fates of their teams. But not always.

headline: Getting Into the Solving Groove
abstract: Saturday is for solving and for shopping.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, CONN. — Saturday at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is a long day for everyone. Puzzle 1 doesn’t drop until 11 a.m., but before that, there is a lot going on. The judges and officials meet to go over the plan for running puzzles to the grading room. The competitors drink multiple cups of coffee to make up for partying the night before and solve practice puzzles to wake up their brains.

headline: Barbra Streisand Apologizes for Her Remarks About Michael Jackson’s Accusers
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Ms. Streisand said two men featured in the new documentary “Leaving Neverland” who claim to have been abused by Mr. Jackson as boys were “thrilled” to be with him.
lead_paragraph: Barbra Streisand apologized on Saturday for saying that two men who accused Michael Jackson of sexually abusing them — as detailed in the documentary “Leaving Neverland” — were “thrilled” to be with him.

headline: Code Switching
abstract: A Trenton Charlson Sunday puzzle, you say? Charlie Oscar Oscar Lima!
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE  — Trenton Charlson is a recent but steady contributor to the Times puzzle; this is his Sunday debut and his 10th offering in a little less than two years (not counting a really inventive variety puzzle). He still needs a Tuesday to hit for the cycle, but that will happen.

headline: Miami Open: Osaka Stunned; Williams Withdraws; Federer Holds On
abstract: Osaka, who lost in three sets, and Serena Williams, who withdrew with an injury, are out of the women’s draw. Roger Federer escaped with a three-set win.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — In a short stretch of Saturday afternoon, the Miami Open lost two of its biggest attractions — and just held on to a third. Top-ranked Naomi Osaka lost her third-round match, 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3 to 27th-seeded Hsieh Su-wei. Midway through Osaka’s match, Serena Williams, an eight-time tournament champion, unexpectedly withdrew, citing a left knee injury.

headline: Cruise Ship Near Norway With Nearly 1,400 Passengers Is Being Evacuated
abstract: Dramatic videos and photos on Twitter showed the ship listing, furniture sliding from one side to the other and water rushing on board.
lead_paragraph: A cruise ship with nearly 1,400 passengers and crew members lost engine power in heavy winds and more than 25-foot waves near the coast of Norway on Saturday, injuring several people and prompting a painstaking, hourslong evacuation, the authorities said.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 24, 2019.
lead_paragraph: METROPOLITAN

headline: Quotation of the Day: Last ISIS Village Falls, and a Caliphate Is Erased
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 24, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “We cannot say that ISIS is finished. It is true that they are finished on the ground as a standing army. But the ISIS threat remains around the globe.”

headline: Rafi Eitan, 92, Israeli Spymaster Who Caught Eichmann, Is Dead
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: He led the team that seized the Nazi architect of the Final Solution in Argentina and later handled the American spy Jonathan Jay Pollard.
lead_paragraph: Rafi Eitan, the canny Israeli spymaster who commanded the Nazi-hunting team that captured Adolf Eichmann in Argentina and many years later was unmasked as the handler of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American Navy intelligence analyst who pleaded guilty to passing on more than 1,000 secret documents to the Israelis, died on Saturday in Tel Aviv. He was 92.

headline: Hannah Grossman, Sarah Williams
abstract: They knew each other in passing for several years from the Los Angeles contemporary art scene before going on a date.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Elizabeth Grossman and Sarah Elizabeth Williams were married March 22 at the Beverly Hills Courthouse in California. Marilyn Szatmary, a deputy commissioner of civil marriage for Los Angeles County, officiated. On March 23, Beth Pickens, a friend of the couple, led them in a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions at the Armory Center for the Arts in Pasadena, Calif.

abstract: The couple met in 2017 at a speakeasy bar in San Francisco and made their relationship official two weeks later.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Louise Friedman and Zachary Thomas Philip Blume were married March 23 at Korakia Pensione, a resort in Palm Springs, Calif. Rabbi Dov Gartenberg officiated.

Johnson Abraham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. On March 22, the couple took part in a celebration ceremony, led by Dr. Shukavak Dasa, a Hindu priest, at the Newport Beach Marriott Hotel in Newport Beach, Calif.

headline: This Week’s Wedding Announcements
abstract: All of the weddings right here on one handy page for you.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Storm Garner and John Jung Wang met in May 2014, shortly after what Ms. Garner described as being “unceremoniously dumped” by her boyfriend. After closing the door on trying to win him back, she opened another when happening upon Mr. Wang’s online dating profile, to which she attached a “liked.” She described it as “so disarmingly genuine, unpretentious, and fun to read.”

headline: Explosion in Syria Kills Driver for NBC News Team
abstract: The blast occurred hours after a U.S.-backed militia announced that the Islamic State had been routed from its last patch of Syrian territory.
lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — A local driver working with a team of journalists from NBC News was killed in an explosion in eastern Syria, the news network’s president said in a statement.

headline: An ISIS Couple’s Troubling Path to Terror Recruiting
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A well-educated pair from the Philippines have been captured in Syria after becoming high-profile recruiters for the terrorist group.
lead_paragraph: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines — She was a Catholic math whiz with an M.B.A. from one of the best universities in the Philippines. He was the Muslim descendant of a sultanate family, schooled in computer science.

headline: Duke’s 1-2 Punch, Each Delivered With a Left Hand
abstract: Zion Williamson and R.J. Barrett are the latest basketball stars to cause headaches for opponents by predominantly shooting and dribbling as lefties.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — To have one excellent left-hander on a basketball team is not uncommon. Bill Russell, David Robinson, James Harden, Manu Ginobili and Tiny Archibald are some of the most accomplished players with a dominant left hand.

headline: How an Owner With Deep Roots Lured Bryce Harper to Lay Down His Own
abstract: “I approach my job as a fan first,” said John Middleton, the Pennsylvania native who gave Harper a 13-year contract in a quest to make the Phillies a model franchise.
lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — John Middleton knew the opportunity when he saw it. He was 9 years old in September 1964, sitting with his father in the upper deck above third base at Connie Mack Stadium in Philadelphia. The Phillies were coasting to the World Series, it seemed, leading the National League by six and a half games with 12 to play.

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: The lives of Supreme Court justices, a poet’s treacherous trip to El Salvador, Mueller-related reading and more.
lead_paragraph: We take the weekend to highlight some of the recent books coverage in The Times:

headline: Its Territory May Be Gone, but the U.S. Fight Against ISIS Is Far From Over
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Thousands of Islamic State fighters are still at large in Iraq and Syria, rearming and regrouping. And the group pose threats elsewhere, in Afghanistan, West Africa and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight to expel the Islamic State from its last shard of territory in Syria may be over. But the United States and its partners still face significant battles against the terrorist group, its affiliates and other networks that are less formally aligned with it elsewhere, in Afghanistan, West Africa and the Philippines.

headline: Hey, Look at Me! I’m a Venture Capitalist
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Start-ups']
abstract: As high-profile start-ups like Lyft, Pinterest and Uber prepare to go public, Silicon Valley venture capitalists are using the moment to shine the spotlight on themselves.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Rick Heitzmann, a venture capitalist at FirstMark Capital, the moment is now.

headline: The Making of ‘The Daily Miracle’
abstract: An NYT Magazine Labs project sent the photographer Christopher Payne to The Times’s printing plant in College Point, Queens, to find the beauty in newsprint and the people who produce it.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $800,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: The Internet’s Endless Appetite for Death Video
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Christchurch, New Zealand, Attack (March 2019)']
abstract: Facebook video of the Christchurch mosque killings showed that people, not algorithms, want to share murder, gore and violence.
lead_paragraph: The video of the Christchurch mosque killings portrays the murder of innocent people from the perspective of their killer, who also used it to disseminate his racist motivations and genocidal worldview. The recording was made with that intention — to spread. This, Facebook said, was among the reasons the company couldn’t quickly eliminate the footage from its platform, which the killer chose as his medium for his broadcast.

headline: Depressed and Anxious? These Video Games Want to Help
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Innovation']
abstract: A growing number of games are taking on mental health issues like depression, anger and post-traumatic stress disorder.
lead_paragraph: In the coming adventure video game Sea of Solitude, the main character — a young woman named Kay — navigates a partly submerged city as she faces a multitude of red-eyed scaly creatures.

headline: Mueller Report, Boeing, ISIS: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: DealBook Special: Everything You Need to Know About the Lyft I.P.O.
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: How much will the company be valued at? What can go wrong? Who stands to get rich? Let us answer all those questions and more.
lead_paragraph: Good Sunday morning, and welcome to a special edition of the DealBook Briefing, where we’ll take a deep dive into Lyft’s upcoming public offering. It’s the first of many decacorns about to go public. (Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up here.)

headline: Heading Into the Finals
abstract: Whose year is it?
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, CONN. — There are two puzzles left to solve at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, and only one is for all the competitors. Puzzle 7 will be solved by all the attendees, and Puzzle 8 will be the final round. Those are solved on the big boards at the front of the ballroom, in front of an audience, with a lively color commentary going on behind them.

headline: Cambodia Faces Major Economic Blow as E.U. Weighs Ending Trade Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The country’s worsening rights record and oppression of the opposition could lead to the revoking of its special access to European markets.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Cambodia faces a serious blow to its economy as the European Union investigates the government’s deteriorating human rights record and considers revoking a special trading deal with the country.

headline: Taliban Kill Dozens of Security Forces in Major Strike in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Two days after the attack, Afghan officials said they still did not have all the details or a death toll, but a lawmaker from the area put the number dead at 65.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The Afghan military has suffered its worst loss of the year in southern Afghanistan, with at least 40 security force members killed in a Taliban attack this past week, but senior officials had still not released a death toll two days later, according to residents and functionaries from the area who spoke on Sunday.

headline: Viking Cruise Ship Stranded Off Norway Reaches Shore After Harrowing Rescue
abstract: The Viking Sky was carrying more than 1,300 people when it sent a mayday alert Saturday. After recovering the use of some engines, the ship finally limped into port.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A cruise ship that set out with more than 1,300 people but became stranded off Norway’s coast finally reached the shore on Sunday afternoon, after rescuers launched a harrowing operation in rough weather to evacuate hundreds of people one by one by helicopter.

headline: Why Lupita Nyong’o’s ‘Us’ Voice Sounds So Creepy
abstract: The story behind one of the year’s most haunting vocal performances.
lead_paragraph: There are no shortage of haunting images in “Us,” the new horror film from Jordan Peele. But many of the movie’s most effective jolts are heard rather than seen, from the chilling score (including a macabre riff on Luniz’s “I Got 5 on It”) on down.

headline: An Ice Marathon Across a Frozen Russian Lake: ‘I Ran Twice as Fast’
abstract: It is one of the world’s most grueling races, 26 miles over Siberia’s Lake Baikal, amid cracking ice and shifting weather. The race attracts a global cast of athletes who want to test their limits.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BAIKAL, Russia — The ice rumbled and then shook underfoot. No one had warned Véronique Messina about that.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Practice your warm-weather cooking: Start with Yotam Ottolenghi’s latest, a baked paella with chorizo and shrimp, and go straight into a big salad.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s spring in America, but if it’s not yet entirely springlike where you sleep, this could be an excellent weekend to model indoors the behavior that will have you cooking outside when the weather heats up: smoke-roasted chicken, say, or fire-scented asparagus with caper salsa. Definitely grilled paella.

headline: Inside Creative Writing’s Premier Talent Factory
abstract: David Dowling’s “A Delicate Aggression” is a history of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop, told through the stories of its students and teachers, including John Irving, Flannery O’Connor and Marilynne Robinson.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable number of notable writers who have studied or taught at the Iowa Writers’ Workshop includes Flannery O’Connor, Robert Lowell, Dylan Thomas, Rita Dove, Sandra Cisneros, Kurt Vonnegut, John Irving and Marilynne Robinson. In “A Delicate Aggression,” David O. Dowling, an associate professor at Iowa’s journalism school, tells the “cultural and industrial history” of the workshop through a series of biographical portraits. He captures writers “in their formative years taking their first tentative steps toward professional careers, forming alliances and rivalries among intimidating world-renowned faculty and high-powered peers.” He writes about the program’s blend of mentoring and marketing, its rigor and its wiles. Below, he discusses the workshop’s founder, Irving defending Vonnegut’s honor in a fight, how Ralph Waldo Emerson helped to inspire this book and more.

headline: At 374,000 Pounds, ‘Big Boy’ Plays Vital Supporting Role at Ground Zero
abstract: A massive steel beam, currently in New Jersey, will be the linchpin of a new performing arts center at the World Trade Center site.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top House Democrats, anxiously awaiting the findings of the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, insisted on Sunday that their own investigations must go on regardless of whether the Justice Department accuses President Trump of wrongdoing.

headline: Review: A Séance (With Leaf Blowers) in ‘Variations on the Main’
abstract: The final show at Jack’s current location is weird and difficult to parse. But it’s nice to know there’s a place for theater like this in New York.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the month, Jack will leave its Brooklyn space for another, bigger Brooklyn space. But before it exits — stage left, right and center — the theater is hosting one last play, going out the way it came in: weirdly.

headline: China Pledges Openness in Hopes of Reaching a Trade Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Top Chinese officials, looking at a skeptical audience both at home and abroad, pledge to open the country’s markets to foreign investment.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Top Chinese economic policymakers promised this weekend that Beijing was ready to open up the country’s economy to more market-based competition and international trade, in the latest sign of strong Chinese interest in ending a multibillion-dollar trade war with the United States.
