headline: Pack Those Binoculars. It’s Peak Bird-Watching Season.
abstract: Hotels and resorts across the country are taking notice of their bird-watching guests, offering educational weekends, watching tours and even full-time birders on staff.
lead_paragraph: It's peak bird-watching season in North America. As millions of birds in the Americas migrate to their summer homes now through May, millions of bird-watchers are taking up binoculars and cameras to spot the Sandhill cranes, Red-Shouldered hawks and thousands of other species flying above.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Parents Who Get Into Edibles
abstract: Should their children be concerned?
lead_paragraph: Bee writes: When I was young, my parents made me terrified of marijuana. They told me if I tried it, the next step was cocaine addiction. Now my parents are in their 60s, and they’re stoned every night on edibles. They once ate Skittles for dinner; it bums me out. Am I right to be concerned about how they’ve decided to live?

headline: Can What We Eat Affect How We Feel?
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Brain', 'Omega-3 Fatty Acids', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Vegetables']
abstract: Nutritional psychiatrists counsel patients on how better eating may be another tool in helping to ease depression and anxiety and may lead to better mental health.
lead_paragraph: The patient, a 48-year-old real estate professional in treatment for anxiety and mild depression, revealed that he had eaten three dozen oysters over the weekend.

headline: Who Botched the Mueller Report?
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Podcasts']
abstract: And should we abolish the Electoral College?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

headline: Should the U.S. Get Rid of the Electoral College?
abstract: Is the system a good way of making sure every citizen’s vote counts?
lead_paragraph: What do you know about the Electoral College? What is its purpose? How does it work? (If you need more information, you might watch the two-minute video, “The Electoral College Explained,” or read the related article, “How Does the Electoral College Work?” from 2016.)

headline: Drawing the Line Between Helping and Helicoptering
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Happiness', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: In the wake of the college bribery scandal, critiques of parents who meddle too much can leave us questioning our everyday instincts to help our children.
lead_paragraph: The recent college admissions scandal has, not surprisingly, reignited concerns about overinvolved parents. Though few parents will intervene to felonious extremes, the widespread critiques of parents who meddle too much can leave us questioning our everyday instincts to help our children.

headline: ‘Swat the Kaiser’ and Stork Stands: The History of Army Physical Fitness
abstract: To some, the Army’s new fitness test represents a forward-thinking approach to physical training for soldiers. But the same has been said of past standards that in hindsight were greatly influenced by cultural fads.
lead_paragraph: Few tasks in American soldiers’ lives are judged as deeply as their performance on the Army’s required semiannual physical-fitness test: Push-ups, situps and a timed two-mile run are used to gauge physical readiness and also, supposedly, readiness for combat. But that long-predictable standard will soon change — radically. By October 2020, all soldiers will instead take the new Army combat-fitness test — a six-event exam that includes heavy deadlifting, a backward medicine-ball toss and dragging a 90-pound sled.

headline: Poem: Spring Letter from the South
abstract: What could be more intimate than a daughter’s sharing with her mother the wonders of childbirth?
lead_paragraph: The letter poem, or epistle, is personal, addressed to a specific individual at a particular point in time. It is a conversation overheard. What could be more intimate than a daughter’s sharing with her mother the wonders of childbirth? Keetje Kuipers’s “Spring Letter from the South” follows the form faithfully, down to an unvoiced “wish you were here”; her beguiling account is like the letter you write in your head before you sit down and everything evaporates, as she gently urges us from the change in seasons toward a contemplation of the cycle of life. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: ‘You Can’t Put It Behind You’: School Shootings Leave Long Trail of Trauma
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Three apparent suicides in Parkland, Fla., and Newtown, Conn., have alarmed people still grappling with the mental trauma created by school shootings.
lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — Kelly Plaur is still having nightmares almost every night. In the mornings, she recounts them to her mother, though the theme is usually the same: the horror she witnessed at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School last year when a gunman opened fire in her classroom, killing two students and injuring four others.

headline: How the Battle Over Israel and Anti-Semitism Is Fracturing American Politics
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Israeli Settlements', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The growing prominence of the B.D.S. movement — and the backlash to it — is widening fault lines from college campuses to Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: On June 9, 2016, the committee tasked with drafting the new Democratic Party platform held its second day of hearings at the Omni Shoreham Hotel, in the upscale Woodley Park neighborhood of Washington. The platform, which is rewritten every presidential-election year, is meant to express a consensus among Democrats on the major issues of the day. The afternoon session, on “America’s role in the world,” included discussions of platform language on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. At stake was whether Democrats would reaffirm the party’s strongly pro-Israel position or make some concessions to the Palestinians.

headline: New York Art Galleries: What to See Right Now
abstract: Gilles Aillaud’s portraits of zoo animals; Paul Mpagi Sepuya’s homoerotic photographs; Christina Forrer’s paintings on a loom; and the BRIC Biennial’s third South Brooklyn Edition.
lead_paragraph: For decades, American art students have learned that the years around 1968 saw the triumph of conceptual art, process-based sculpture, environmental interventions and body-oriented performances — and only now,  at half a century’s distance, are we admitting that figurative painting had its place too in the late-60s art world, especially in Western Europe. Gilles Aillaud (1928-2005) was a central actor of Narrative Figuration during Paris’s years of student revolt, as well as a set designer at Europe’s top avant-garde theaters. But “Paintings 1964-1976,” with eight coolly composed portraits of animals in zoos, is the first showcase of his works in New York since a show at Gladstone Gallery in 1982.

headline: By the Book: Henry Louis Gates Jr.
abstract: The scholar and host of the PBS series “Reconstruction,” whose latest books are “Dark Sky Rising” and “Stony the Road,” is a productive beach reader: “I read more during two months on the Vineyard … than I do the entire rest of the year.”
lead_paragraph: The scholar and host of the PBS series “Reconstruction,” whose latest books are “Dark Sky Rising” and “Stony the Road,” is a productive beach reader: “I read more during two months on the Vineyard … than I do the entire rest of the year.”

headline: Salman Rushdie Reviews a Sweeping Debut About the Roots of Modern Zambia
abstract: In “The Old Drift,” Namwali Serpell spins a multigenerational, magical-realist tale of the East African nation from colonialism to the future.
lead_paragraph: THE OLD DRIFT By Namwali Serpell

headline: Pete Buttigieg (It’s ‘Boot-Edge-Edge’) Is Making Waves in the 2020 Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Pete Buttigieg may have a challenging last name and an unconventional résumé. But he’s drawing big crowds and has jumped to third place in a poll of Iowa voters.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. — Somewhere between Pete Buttigieg being mistaken for a teenager making a promposal, and answering a question in Norwegian, and proclaiming that it was millennials’ turn to lead “at the highest level,” South Carolina got a crash course in a new Democratic celebrity.

headline: 36 Hours in Rio de Janeiro
abstract: A weekend in this ever-surprising Brazilian city might include caipirinhas on the beach; capuchin monkeys on a hike; and music, food and history everywhere.
lead_paragraph: To come to this sprawling, dynamic Brazilian city without preconceptions, whether they’re about bikinis or President Jair Bolsonaro, is just about impossible. But Rio constantly finds ways to surprise — whether it’s a friendly resident walking you to a shop you just can’t find; sobering evidence of the city’s slave trade; or the discovery that food tastes best standing on a sidewalk surrounded by the lyrical sound of Portuguese and accompanied by a beer so cold it’ll make your fillings hurt. From beach to museum, church to market, Rio is a city constantly defying its own myths and encourages visitors to join in with unbridled enthusiasm.

headline: Why Logic Wrote a Novel
abstract: The rapper, whose real name is Bobby Hall, has branched out with a debut novel, “Supermarket.”
lead_paragraph: Bobby Hall, better known as the Grammy-nominated rapper Logic, started writing his debut novel, “Supermarket,” four years ago.   He had released “The Incredible True Story,” a dystopian concept album in which two men search for a planet named Paradise in the wake of Earth’s destruction, and finished the script for a film, “Everything Must Go,” now in development with J.J. Abrams’s production company, Bad Robot.

headline: Iran’s Allies Feel the Pain of American Sanctions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Iran’s financial crisis, worsened by American sanctions, has taken a toll on its allied Syrian militias and Hezbollah, who are showing signs of financial strain.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian militiamen paid by Iran have seen their salaries slashed. Projects Iran promised to help Syria’s ailing economy have stalled. Even employees of Hezbollah, the Lebanese group that has long served as Iran’s closest Arab ally, say they have missed paychecks and lost other perks.

headline: Trump Owns the Economy Now, for Better or Worse
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Federal Reserve has halted rate increases. Tax cuts and tariffs have taken hold. Now the president must prove the naysayers wrong about the future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is getting exactly what he wants on the economy, but it may not last.

headline: Prosecuting R. Kelly
abstract: The singer, trailed by allegations for years, has now been charged with sexual abuse. We hear from the Chicago prosecutor on the other side of the case.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Down by the Bay, in Brooklyn
abstract: A Manhattan transplant finds more serenity and space for his children in the waterfront neighborhood of Red Hook.
lead_paragraph: Eliot Ferguson, who is originally from Florida, arrived in New York as a drummer at the age of 22. He and his older brother bought a building in TriBeCa, gutted and rebuilt it, and opened a recording studio there. He lived on the top floor. Later, Mr. Ferguson bought a two-bedroom condominium in SoHo, where he lived with his wife, and sold the TriBeCa building.

headline: Meet the Long-Suffering Fan Behind Our Miracle Mets Section
abstract: Jay Schreiber, a former deputy sports editor for The Times, drew on his lifelong relationship with the Mets in revisiting the team’s 1969 season.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Huawei Security ‘Defects’ Are Found by British Authorities
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Wireless Communications', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Britain bolstered White House claims that the Chinese company poses a cybersecurity risk. But the report stopped short of calling for a ban on Huawei products.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British review of Huawei found “significant” security problems with the Chinese company’s telecommunications equipment, a conclusion that supports a United States effort to ban it from next-generation wireless networks.

headline: At Least 25 Die in Office Tower Fire in Dhaka, Bangladesh
abstract: A fire official said that at least 70 people had been injured, and witnesses said they saw several people falling from the building in an effort to escape the flames.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A fire broke out on Thursday in a large office tower in Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, killing at least 25 people and injuring several dozen others, officials said.

headline: Stephen Colbert Calls Mike Lee the ‘Jar Jar Binks of the Senate’
abstract: After the Republican senator used absurd graphics to send up the Green New Deal, the “Late Show” host gave him a taste of his own medicine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: A Pinter Marathon Saves the Best for Last
abstract: A revelatory new production of “Betrayal” starring Tom Hiddleston comes after a season of the playwright’s one-act plays.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Talk about saving the best for last. For six months, the Harold Pinter Theater has been given over to a unique sequence of Pinter one-acts, presented under the curatorial eye of Jamie Lloyd, who directed some of these lesser-known plays himself. The results tested the receptiveness of theatergoers in the West End, not exactly a climate for classy esoterica.

abstract: Thursday: What to know about the hundreds of confirmed cases in the state.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: There’s Only One Way Out for Cuba’s Dismal Economy
abstract: The island’s economy is neither efficient nor competitive. To move forward it must deepen and accelerate reforms. The market socialism model could provide a way.
lead_paragraph: For the past 60 years, Cuba has been unable to finance its imports with its own exports and generate appropriate, sustainable growth without substantial aid and subsidies from a foreign nation. This is the longstanding legacy of Cuba’s socialist economy.

headline: Thinking of a Jumbotron Proposal? Some Say, Ugh. Others, Say Yes.
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Social Media']
abstract: Splashy proposals at sporting events are often considered tacky. Yet hundreds of these public, grandiose gestures happen each year.
lead_paragraph: Jumbotron proposals have become as much a part of baseball as the seventh-inning stretch — no matter that they are often considered tacky and in bad taste.

headline: Amy Klobuchar Proposes $1 Trillion Infrastructure Plan
abstract: The first policy rollout of Ms. Klobuchar’s campaign for president would fix a wide range of the country’s infrastructure, from roads and bridges to water systems and internet access.
lead_paragraph: Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota unveiled a plan Thursday to spend a trillion dollars in federal funds to upgrade the country’s infrastructure, the first policy announcement of her campaign for the Democratic nomination for president.

headline: The Implicit Punishment of Daring to Go to College When Poor
abstract: A documentary to be screened on Capitol Hill next month, in which I am featured, chronicles the experience of low-income students navigating college admissions.
lead_paragraph: When I heard that federal prosecutors were charging 50 people in six states for a college admissions bribery scheme and read the accounts that followed, outlining all of the other extensive, mostly legal, help that applicants from rich families get, it underscored how different the admissions experience was for me and my high school classmates in Canarsie.

headline: Do You Understand Elizabeth Warren’s Plan for Fixing Big Tech?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Politicians have lots of ideas for regulating big tech. Here’s how to know which ones work.
lead_paragraph: This election season, Americans are going to hear a lot about regulating big tech. Senator Elizabeth Warren has already kicked off that debate, and it would be the tone-deaf candidate who wasn’t alert to the increasing anxiety among the public over the power Silicon Valley giants wield. According to a 2018 survey by Pew Research Center, 57 percent of Democrats and 44 percent of Republicans feel that big tech companies should be regulated more than they are now.

headline: Is Trump Keyser Söze — Or Inspector Clouseau?
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Maybe the president brilliantly played the media. Or maybe we just played ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Maybe we’ve had this all wrong.

headline: The Flood of Court Cases That Threaten Abortion
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'States (US)', "Women's Rights", 'Constitution (US)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Republican presidents sought judges who could be counted on to oppose abortion. The voices of those judges come through clearly in cases now making their way to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: With all that’s going on in the world of law, I didn’t plan on writing about abortion again so soon. But as the tide of Supreme Court-bound abortion cases turns rapidly into a flood, it’s become a challenge even for people with a deep interest in the future of the abortion right to keep track of what’s happening and of which cases to worry about most. Thus, this column.

headline: Eyes on the Road! (Your Car Is Watching)
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Computer Vision', 'Privacy']
abstract: As more technology creeps into the front seat to help drivers, so too will systems that eavesdrop on and monitor them.
lead_paragraph: The automobile, in American life, has long been a hallmark of freedom. A teenager’s first driver’s license offers freedom from Mom and Dad. A new car and the open road bring the freedom to chase the American dream. But as more technology creeps in to help drivers, so, too, will systems that eavesdrop on and monitor them, necessitated not by convenience but by new safety concerns.

headline: Manchester United Names Ole Gunnar Solskjaer as Full-Time Manager
abstract: The Premier League club said that Solskjaer, who was brought in as a temporary replacement after José Mourinho was fired, had signed a three-year contract.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Manchester United said on Thursday that Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, the club’s former striker who parachuted in as temporary manager after José Mourinho was fired in December, has signed a three-year contract to take the job on a permanent basis.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Saudi Arabia Wanted Cash. Aramco Just Obliged.
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s giant oil company announced yesterday that it had bought 70 percent of the kingdom’s state-controlled petrochemical company for $69 billion.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. (Want this by email? Sign up here.)

headline: ‘Relaxer’ Review: Help! He’s Sitting and He Can’t Get Up
abstract: Sad and strange and defiantly gross, Joel Potrykus’s “Relaxer” is a compassionate survival tale swirling with childhood trauma.
lead_paragraph: The films of Joel Potrykus have been described as slacker comedies, featuring, as they often do, shambolic losers barely surviving somewhere between working poor and utter destitution. To me, though, they’re something else entirely: cracked symphonies of anguish and humiliation.

headline: ‘Diane’ Review: A Vibrant Tale of Love, Sisterhood and Decline
abstract: Mary Kay Place is astonishing as a weary widow dealing with guilt, heartache and a diminishing circle of friends.
lead_paragraph: Buoyed by a movie lover’s wish list of warmly familiar female faces, “Diane,” the remarkable new film from the writer and director Kent Jones, is in part a meditation on dying that feels wondrously alive.

headline: ‘The Burial of Kojo’ Review: A Dazzling Modern Fable
abstract: The Ghana-born musician Blitz Bazawule makes a stunning feature directing debut that comes alive with rhythm and color.
lead_paragraph: When musicians turn to film directing, it doesn’t always work out. Ask anyone who’s seen Bob Dylan’s nearly-five-hour musical romance “Renaldo and Clara” (although that oddity does have its wary admirers). But it more than works out with “The Burial of Kojo,” written, directed and scored by Blitz Bazawule, a Ghana-born musician now based in New York who traveled back to his birth country to make this dazzling modern fable.

headline: ‘The Chaperone’ Review: A Matron and a Movie Star Take a Jazz-Age Journey
abstract: Michael Engler’s dull period piece follows a conservative woman who accompanies a young silent film star on a trip to New York City.
lead_paragraph: “The Chaperone” is about a woman who abandons her literal and figurative corsets and discovers her bliss. The year is 1922, the woman is a genteel Presbyterian wife named Norma (Elizabeth McGovern), and the starchy setting is Wichita, Kansas. To sell this heavy-handed foundation-garment metaphor, the director Michael Engler and his screenwriter, Julian Fellowes (working from the book by Laura Moriarty), wrap it in the stardust of the larval silent film star Louise Brooks (Haley Lu Richardson), who, as a precocious 15-year-old, is chaperoned by Norma to Manhattan to study dance.

headline: ‘The Last’ Review: A Revelation Leaves a Family Shattered
abstract: This drama, written and directed by Jeff Lipsky, explores a monstrous idea with complexity.
lead_paragraph: “The Last,” written and directed by Jeff Lipsky, begins on the first day of Rosh Hashana. In a park, a close-knit family performs a prayer ritual. Two characters in their early 30s, Josh (AJ Cedeño) and Olivia (Jill Durso), are soon to be married. Josh is a Modern Orthodox Jew, and Olivia has converted from Catholicism to Judaism. Josh’s father, Harry, is a sardonic agnostic. Claire, Josh’s great-grandmother, stays mostly silent but is clearly full of affection.

headline: ‘Slut in a Good Way’ Review: And Then They Staged a Sex Strike
abstract: In this coming-of-age comedy directed by Sophie Lorain, first comes love. Then comes rebellion.
lead_paragraph: In “Slut in a Good Way,” teenagers staff a toy store. But unlike their patrons, who visit for the stuffed animals, the young cashiers and stockists prefer playing games with one another.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Help Get Rid of Distractions
abstract: You and your phone need a break.
lead_paragraph: If you want to reclaim your attention and not be so dependent on the highly addictive device in your pocket, you’ll need to be proactive to come up with ways to untangle yourself from smartphone dependence.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | April 3, 2019
abstract: Look closely at this graph, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 4, 2019

headline: ‘Tigerland’ Review: Conservation Documentary Lacks Claws
abstract: The film falls into a common trap of advocacy documentaries, which is to inform on an urgent issue without a particularly urgent cinematic narrative to match it.
lead_paragraph: According to “Tigerland,” Kailash Sankhala, a noted conservationist from India, believed that to save the tiger it was important to give the public a sense of its beauty. This documentary, directed by Ross Kauffman, at least partly illustrates that principle. You leave with an appreciation for the movements and instincts of an animal of which there are fewer than 4,000 left in the wild, The New York Times wrote in October.

headline: Hammer Museum Auction at Sotheby’s Will Benefit Artist Fund
abstract: Some 35 contemporary artists are donating pieces to the auction, which will take place in New York in May.
lead_paragraph: Artists can be reluctant to part with their work, especially if they’re not being paid. But on Thursday, the Hammer Museum at UCLA announced that more than 35 contemporary artists, including Ed Ruscha and Vija Celmins, will donate pieces to raise money for the museum’s new Artist Fund. Their work will be auctioned off in New York at Sotheby’s in May.

headline: Power and Love: What We Can All Learn From Wagner’s ‘Ring’
abstract: In a divisive moment in American politics, Wagner’s four-opera epic feels like a cautionary tale of a power-hungry ruler.
lead_paragraph: True to form, an autocratic executive wrapping up a real estate deal is trying to wiggle out of paying contractors. The project, a gleaming, fortified executive residence and business headquarters, is a veritable castle in the sky. His idea was to get all his subordinates — including his aggrieved wife, obsequious family members and a dirty trickster — under one roof so he can better control them as he continues enhancing his dominion and power.

headline: Afro Emojis Don’t Exist. These Women Want to Change That.
keywords: ['Hair', 'Emojis and Emoticons', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Standards and Standardization']
abstract: “I want to create a space where we can bring that big-hair energy and celebrate our roots in digital spaces,” said one of the women behind a petition to add the emoji.
lead_paragraph: Many people connected to the African diaspora have Afros. And like anyone else, they send emojis to their friends — a zombie, say, or a mermaid or a genie.

headline: Trump Criticizes Central American Nations on Border Security
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Border Barriers', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The remarks came a day after the homeland security secretary struck what she called a historic agreement with some of those countries to help strengthen security on the southwestern border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump criticized Mexico, El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras on Thursday for accepting monetary aid from the United States but doing nothing in return, a day after his homeland security secretary struck what she described as a historic agreement with three of those same countries to help strengthen security on the United States’ southwestern border.

headline: Theresa May Put Her Head on the Block for Her Brexit Deal. It Might Not Be Enough.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The British prime minister made one final gamble, offering to resign in exchange for the votes to get her withdrawal agreement over the line.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One thing that we have learned about Prime Minister Theresa May over the last two years: She does not give up. Even when her task seems impossible, when she fails on the most public stage imaginable, when she is sick, and tired, and subjected to another round of jeers and sneers from the boys’ club at Westminster. Every morning she gets up, dusts herself off, and gets on with the job.

headline: Baseball Was My Life. Then I Stopped Being Able to Throw the Ball.
abstract: It’s called the yips, and it’s a sudden inability to play. I had to find my way out of it.
lead_paragraph: I quit playing baseball when I was 11 years old. That was the cutoff for girls; after that point, we had to switch to softball, and I wasn’t having it.

headline: Shambles
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Referendums', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A Brexit scoreboard: Solutions 0, Chaos 8.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.

headline: Deadly Explosion Outside Crowded Restaurant in Mogadishu
abstract: The explosion on a busy road in the Somalia capital killed at least 15 people and destroyed two restaurants and cars parked in the area.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A car bomb exploded on Thursday near a hotel and restaurant in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, killing at least 15 people, rescue services said, in a strike on a busy area that has been targeted by Islamist militants in the past.

headline: Brexit Process Remains Deadlocked, but Theresa May Plans a Last-Ditch Vote on Friday
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Some Conservative lawmakers struggled to keep the prime minister’s deal alive as others said that her offer to resign was not enough to win approval.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s tottering efforts to leave the European Union remained at an impasse on Thursday as allies of Prime Minister Theresa May tried to keep her deal alive in the face of unbending opposition.

headline: Pennsylvania Police Chief Charged in Child Rape Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Police', 'Child Pornography', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: After a girl reported sexual abuse, it took seven years for criminal charges to be brought against two suspects, including the Weissport police chief.
lead_paragraph: A case was opened in 2012, when a 12-year-old girl in Pennsylvania told her substitute teacher that a man had sexually assaulted her for years, and the teacher then told the police, according to a statement from the state attorney general’s office.

headline: It’s Opening Day. He Made Sure Oakland Coliseum Was Ready.
abstract: Thursday: An interview with the Athletics’ head of stadium operations; Kamala Harris’s first big policy rollout; and “Us”
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Russia ‘Has to Get Out’ of Venezuela, Trump Says
abstract: President Trump met with with Fabiana Rosales, the wife of Juan Guaidó, on Wednesday. The White House recognizes Mr. Guaidó as Venezuela’s interim president and has warned the Russian government to stay out of Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: President Trump met with with Fabiana Rosales, the wife of Juan Guaidó, on Wednesday. The White House recognizes Mr. Guaidó as Venezuela’s interim president and has warned the Russian government to stay out of Venezuela.

headline: R. Kelly Accuser Gives Her Account Publicly for First Time
abstract: Lanita Carter, one of the women the R&B singer is charged with abusing, told “CBS This Morning” that he demanded oral sex, then masturbated and spat on her face.
lead_paragraph: When R. Kelly was arrested on child pornography charges in 2002, Lanita Carter, his hairdresser, was one of his staunchest defenders.

headline: Where Will Sellers Get What They’re Asking?
abstract: If you’re listing a home in one of these neighborhoods in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, you may well get more than you’re asking — or a lot less.
lead_paragraph: With peak spring listing season upon us, buyers and sellers in New York City may be wondering how well homes are selling in their neighborhoods, and whether those homes are likely to go for more or less than the asking prices.

headline: Billie Eilish Is Not Your Typical 17-Year-Old Pop Star. Get Used to Her.
abstract: A teenager with more than a billion plays already, Eilish will release her angsty debut album, and may very well become a household name.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Even before she turned 17 in December, the singer Billie Eilish had accomplished nearly all of the modern prerequisites for pop stardom and then some: Her homemade songs, written only with her older brother, had been streamed more than a billion times on digital platforms; she’d played increasingly large sold-out concerts to delirious fans (and their patient parents); appeared with Ellen DeGeneres and Jimmy Fallon; and collected some 15 million followers on Instagram.

headline: Facebook Engages in Housing Discrimination With Its Ad Practices, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Fair Housing Act (1968)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Social Media', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The Department of Housing and Urban Development sued the company for violating the federal Fair Housing Act by limiting who sees ads based on characteristics like race, religion and national origin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Housing and Urban Development sued Facebook on Thursday for engaging in housing discrimination by allowing advertisers to restrict who is able to see ads on the platform based on characteristics like race, religion and national origin.

headline: By the Book: Richard Powers
abstract: The author, most recently, of “The Overstory” was from an early age a “fan of awe”: “I liked reading about diatoms and stars, things from four hundred million years ago or a hundred thousand years from now.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “The Overstory” was from an early age a “fan of awe”: “I liked reading about diatoms and stars, things from four hundred million years ago or a hundred thousand years from now.”

headline: Top Democrat Assails Bernhardt’s Ethics at Senate Hearing on His Interior Secretary Nomination
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Federal Lands', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Lawmakers must decide whether Mr. Bernhardt, who has faced conflict-of-interest criticisms, is the right person to oversee some 500 million acres of public land as well as the nation’s coastal waters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s choice to lead the Interior Department, David Bernhardt, a former oil lobbyist who has been accused of conflicts of interest, faced questioning Thursday from senators who must decide whether he is the right person to oversee some 500 million acres of public land and vast coastal waters.

headline: Teaching With NYT Virtual Reality Across Subjects
abstract: Virtual reality journalism can serve as a powerful educational tool to grab students’ attention and get them excited about complex subjects.
lead_paragraph: Update, Nov. 6, 2020: We have an updated version of this V.R. teaching resource.

headline: Root, Root, Root for the Home Team (or Maybe the One You Bet On)
abstract: Here comes the baseball season, which means, in more and more of the United States, here comes the baseball betting season.
lead_paragraph: Here comes the baseball season, which means, in more and more of the United States, here comes the baseball betting season.

headline: Mueller Report Exceeds 300 Pages, Raising Questions About Four-Page Summary
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The page count suggests the special counsel detailed his conclusions beyond Justice Department requirements. And it raises questions about what the attorney general might have left out of his summary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The still-secret report on Russian interference in the 2016 election submitted last week by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, was more than 300 pages long, the Justice Department acknowledged on Thursday.

headline: This Guy Actually Has a Perfect Bracket. So Far.
abstract: Yeah, he had Oregon. Yeah, he had Central Florida. Yeah, he even had U.C. Irvine.
lead_paragraph: When did your bracket get busted? Was it Thursday afternoon, or did you make it into the evening? Was it when Murray State beat Marquette or when Liberty beat Mississippi State?

headline: New York Sues Sackler Family Members and Drug Distributors
abstract: The state’s lawsuit offers detail on methods allegedly used to flood the market with opioids, fueling an epidemic.
lead_paragraph: As investigators closed in on Purdue Pharma, the maker of the opioid painkiller OxyContin, more than a decade ago, members of the family that owns the company began shifting hundreds of millions of dollars from the business to themselves through offshore entities, the state of New York alleged in a lawsuit on Thursday.

headline: ‘Us’ Reflects a Mirror Image of ‘The Twilight Zone’
abstract: For his latest horror hit, Jordan Peele appears to draw inspiration from Rod Serling’s classic series in more ways than one.
lead_paragraph: Major spoilers for “Us” (and some decades-old episodes of “The Twilight Zone”) are ahead.

headline: Do Periods Get Worse as You Age?
abstract: Periods can get heavier and more painful for some women after the age of 40. Sometimes it is a nuisance and sometimes it is a cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: It seems to me that my periods have gotten heavier and more painful now that I’m in my early 40s. Am I crazy? If true, is this a cause for concern?

headline: How a Young Activist Set Off a #MeToo Avalanche in Mexico
abstract: Tweets over the weekend inspired more than 100 women to come forward. But in a place where violence and impunity are common, many accusers remain anonymous.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The #MeToo movement, nearly dormant in Mexico, was jump-started when an activist posted messages on Twitter last weekend in which she accused a young writer of having beaten and abused more than 10 women.

headline: What if Churchill Had Been Prime Minister in 1919?
abstract: More than most, he understood the grave challenges facing the West at the end of World War I.
lead_paragraph: At 11 a.m. on Nov. 11, 1918, Winston Churchill was looking out of the window of his Ministry of Munitions, toward Trafalgar Square in London, waiting for the great bell of Big Ben to sound, telling Britons that World War I was finally over.

headline: This Is America. Do You Belong Here? Navigating the Checkpoints of the Southwest Border
abstract: In this week’s Crossing the Border newsletter, a Times reporter answers the question: “Are you an American citizen?” Again and again and again.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Crossing the Border, a limited-run weekly newsletter from The New York Times. Like what you see? Send this to a friend. If someone forwarded it to you, sign up here to have the next issue delivered to your inbox.

headline: Wow Air, an Icelandic Budget Airline, Suspends Service
abstract: Efforts to raise money had failed, prompting the company to cease all flights on Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: Wow Air, an Icelandic budget airline that has been scrambling for money, ceased operations on Thursday after talks over financing fell apart.

headline: College Hockey’s Depth Is Reflected in Men’s Tournament Field
abstract: Arizona State and American International College are in, while traditional powers like Boston College and North Dakota are out, when the tournament begins Friday.
lead_paragraph: For many years, the N.C.A.A. Division I men’s hockey tournament was a celebration of the sport’s aristocracy.

headline: At 71, She’s Never Felt Pain or Anxiety. Now Scientists Know Why.
keywords: ['Pain', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: Scientists discovered a previously unidentified genetic mutation in a Scottish woman. They hope it could lead to the development of new pain treatment.
lead_paragraph: She’d been told that childbirth was going to be painful. But as the hours wore on, nothing bothered her — even without an epidural.

headline: Us
abstract: We dissect Jordan Peele’s new psychological thriller.
lead_paragraph: We dissect Jordan Peele’s new psychological thriller, “Us,” and discuss the film’s central question (WITHOUT SPOILERS): Are any of us ever truly free from the past?

headline: JPMorgan’s Role in Nigerian Oil Deal Has Come Back to Haunt It
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: A JPMorgan Chase account in London was used to send roughly $900 million to government officials involved in a scheme to profit from an offshore oil field.
lead_paragraph: Under the rule of the Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha more than 20 years ago, a handful of high-ranking government officials looted billions of dollars from the country’s coffers.

headline: A Watchful Eye on Facebook’s Advertising Practices
abstract: Is the social media giant finally facing consequences for ads that discriminate?
lead_paragraph: Before the Department of Housing and Urban Development on Thursday announced that it has charged Facebook with violating the Fair Housing Act by enabling advertisers to engage in housing discrimination, Facebook said that it would change its ad-targeting methods to forbid discriminatory advertisements about housing, employment and credit opportunities. This plan, announced last week, is part of its settlement agreement with the civil rights groups that filed suits against the company over the past few years. The substantive terms are not radical. But they outline a basic framework for how policymakers might begin thinking about reforming big tech in ways that are suited to our times.

headline: The People Who Won’t Be Duped
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Algeria’s army finally turns its back on the president. But the protesters want much more than that.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For some weeks now, Algerians have been taking to the streets for peaceful demonstrations. The now-historic protests climax every Friday, when people of all ages and backgrounds come together to march and chant slogans and songs.

headline: Les Algériens ne sont pas dupes
abstract: L’armée tourne enfin le dos au président, mais le peuple veut beaucoup plus que cela.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Depuis plusieurs semaines, Algériennes et Algériens défilent pacifiquement dans la rue — des manifestations historiques dont le point d’orgue est une rencontre hebdomadaire, le vendredi, où toutes les catégories sociales et d’âge se rejoignent pour battre le pavé et rivaliser en slogans et chants. À l’origine, les revendications exprimaient un clair refus d’un cinquième mandat pour le président Abdelaziz Bouteflika, au pouvoir depuis 1999 et dans un état de santé si délabré qu’on ne le voyait plus en public que par le biais d’un portrait encadré (devant lequel de nombreux officiels s’inclinaient).

headline: Turkish Trial of U.S. Consular Employee Highlights Rift in Relations
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: After 18 months in solitary confinement, a Turkish employee of the United States Consulate was denied release, despite American protests that the charges are baseless.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul courtroom opened a window on the state of American-Turkish relations as Metin Topuz, a Turkish employee of the United States Consulate in Istanbul, went on trial in one of several cases that showcase American powerlessness in the face of the intransigence of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline: The Author Who Tased Himself to Reveal the Failures of High-Tech Policing
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Stun Guns']
abstract: In “Thin Blue Lie” Matt Stroud untangles the web of law enforcement agencies, for-profit corporations and politicians that have put technology at the center of policing.
lead_paragraph: THIN BLUE LIE The Failure of High-Tech Policing By Matt Stroud

headline: Tunisia Commission Releases Final Report on 50 Years of Dictatorship
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Archives and Records', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The Truth and Dignity Commission published an archive of human rights violations and named President Béji Caïd Essebsi for his role in trials in 1963.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The Truth and Dignity Commission of Tunisia released its final report this week on more than 50 years of dictatorship in the country, a devastating, 2,000-page archive of torture and human rights violations that is intended to prevent the return of authoritarian rule.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: There’s a saying in journalism (and in other endeavors, with minor variations) that twice is a coincidence, three times is a trend. If that’s true, we have a bunch of coincidences for you this week. There are two Supreme Court biographies: Evan Thomas’s “First,” about Sandra Day O’Connor, and Joan Biskupic’s “The Chief,” about John Roberts. There are two spy books: the novel “American Spy” and the political history “Spies of No Country.” Two memoirs, by Carolyn Forché and Mitchell S. Jackson. And weirdly — which is to say, coincidentally — two books with the word “betrayal” in the subtitle. The lesson here may only be that eclecticism likes company. And that sounds like a trend.

headline: Grenfell Tower Study Finds Many Toxic Chemicals Near Fire Site
keywords: ['Grenfell Tower Fire (June, 2017)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Asthma', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: Almost a year and a half after the fire that killed 72 people, researchers found extremely high levels of substances that could pose numerous health risks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A toxic cocktail of chemicals released by the Grenfell Tower fire still contaminated the London area around the building almost a year and a half later, and could pose a serious health risk to local residents and survivors of the blaze, new research has found.

headline: Supreme Court Refuses to Block Ban on Bump Stocks
abstract: Challengers said the Trump administration exceeded its authority in banning the devices, which the Justice Department has said helps transform semiautomatic weapons into fully automatic machine guns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday refused to block a Trump administration initiative banning bump stocks, the attachments that enable semiautomatic rifles to fire in sustained, rapid bursts.

headline: Oliver North Showed Republicans the Way Out
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Iran-Contra Affair', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Watergate Affair']
abstract: Belligerence, shamelessness and partisanship can take you far.
lead_paragraph: Watergate, the modern template for an impeachment-worthy scandal, has informed much of the coverage of the Russia scandal, from congressional inquiries to the special counsel’s investigation into President Trump and his campaign. Central questions — Did the president conspire to illegally influence the election? Did he obstruct justice? — have clear antecedents in Watergate. And Trump himself bears more than a slight resemblance to Richard Nixon at his most paranoid and intransigent.

headline: Qatar National Museum Tells a Country’s Story at Every Turn
abstract: The building designed by the architect Jean Nouvel has been praised worldwide, but its focus is first and foremost a local one, the museum’s chairwoman said.
lead_paragraph: One reviewer has called it “breathtaking” and a building that “leaves most state-of-the-art museums in the shade.”

headline: Grindr Is Owned by a Chinese Firm, and the U.S. Is Trying to Force It to Sell
keywords: ['Online Dating', 'Mobile Applications', 'United States International Relations', 'Computer Security', 'Foreign Investments', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is forcing a Chinese company to sell its stake in Grindr, a gay dating app, over national security concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is expanding its efforts to block Chinese acquisitions in the United States, moving to force a Chinese firm that owns Grindr, the gay dating app, to relinquish control over concerns that Beijing could use personal information to blackmail or influence American officials, according to people familiar with the situation.

headline: Quebec Proposes Bill Barring Public Employees From Wearing Head Scarves at Work
abstract: The bill would also ban the wearing of religious symbols like Catholic crosses, Jewish skull caps and Sikh turbans while public employees are at work.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — The Quebec government on Thursday proposed a bill barring public school teachers, judges, police officers and other public employees from wearing religious symbols including Muslim head scarves while working, a move that could aggravate simmering cultural tensions in the province.

headline: An Iceberg Twice the Size of New York City Is About to Split From Antarctica
abstract: Scientists say the break could trigger further retreat of the Brunt ice shelf.
lead_paragraph: Scientists say the break could trigger further retreat of the Brunt ice shelf.

headline: Saudi Women’s Rights Activists Granted Release, but Their Trial Continues
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Women and Girls', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Torture']
abstract: Three women arrested last year, in a case that has drawn international attention, were granted temporary release by a criminal court. But the charges against them were not dismissed.
lead_paragraph: A Saudi court on Thursday temporarily freed three of the women’s rights activists standing trial in a case that has drawn international criticism of the kingdom’s human rights record.

headline: In 2020 Southern Primaries, Victory for Democrats Begins With Black Women
abstract: Kamala Harris and Beto O’Rourke took different approaches, but they both reached out to black women in campaign swings through the South recently.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — One presidential candidate was a black female senator from California, speaking with subdued precision and being received like distant kin at what used to be the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s church in Atlanta.

headline: Here’s What Happens When You Give Unsolicited Parenting Advice
abstract: Nothing good, that’s what.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I visited our son’s family in another state. While there, I noticed my daughter-in-law treating their older son (17) almost cruelly. (She yelled at him for walking the dog when it was too hot outside!) After several instances, I said to her: “I’ve always thought you were a wonderful parent, but the way you’re treating your son isn’t right. Can we talk? I have some advice you can take or leave.” Now she won’t take my calls, even after several apology messages. My son won’t get involved. (F.Y.I., she doesn’t speak to her own family; she has “issues” with them.) What to do?

headline: Weather Channel Is Sued Over Fatal Crash Involving Storm Chasers
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Weather', 'Tornadoes']
abstract: Corbin Jaeger was killed in 2017 when two storm chasers ran a stop sign at about 70 miles per hour, the lawsuit says. All three died in the crash.
lead_paragraph: The mother of a man who was killed in a traffic collision involving two storm chasers has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the Weather Channel that seeks $125 million in damages.

headline: ‘A Vigilante’ Review: Vengeance Is Hers
abstract: Olivia Wilde stars as an avenger of domestic-abuse victims in Sarah Daggar-Nickson’s satisfyingly lean, mean genre movie.
lead_paragraph: The monsters in “A Vigilante” look deceptively ordinary. One wears an everyday business suit and tie; another is dressed in a simple T-shirt and pants, though it’s hard to make out what he’s wearing because he’s trussed up, on his knees, beaten down. Abusers, each endures the kind of ostensibly righteous retribution that tends to be visited on men by other men in exploitation flicks like “Death Wish.” On occasion, a woman steps into the vigilante role — at times, after she’s raped, as in “I Spit on Your Grave” — seeking personal payback through a violent cleansing that can widen into a feminist critique.

headline: The Jussie Smollett Case: Key Questions
abstract: The convoluted affair surrounding one of the stars of the television series “Empire” has taken many surprising turns. Though the charges against him have been dropped, the story is far from over.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Ever since Jussie Smollett, a star of the television series “Empire,” first claimed in January that he was the victim of a bizarre hate crime on a Chicago street, the case has taken one baffling twist after another, attracted wide attention on social media and inflamed passions on all sides. The police initially investigated the incident as a possible hate crime and made arrests, but later came to doubt Mr. Smollett’s account. He was accused of staging the incident, arrested and indicted, only to have prosecutors unexpectedly drop the charges on Tuesday.

headline: South Carolina Fifth Grader Dies After School Fight, Officials Say
abstract: The student had gotten into a fight with another fifth grader at school and died two days later, officials in Colleton County said.
lead_paragraph: A fifth-grade student in South Carolina has died after a fight at her elementary school this week, a devastating outcome that left her community shocked with grief and spurred a discussion about how to handle painful issues of bullying and violence in the classroom.

headline: Meet the Australian Who Guards Duke’s Best Every Day. He Has Seen Things.
abstract: For three years, Jack White, a stout (and game) 6-foot-7 junior forward, has stared down Duke’s future lottery picks in practice. It has been quite an education.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Jack White arrived at Duke in the summer of 2016, a hard-working, eager kid from Traralgon, Australia, thinking he was ready for big-time college basketball. He had no idea exactly what he was about to face.

headline: Film Club: ‘I Am Not Untouchable. I Just Have My Period.’
abstract: How do a culture’s or society’s values and beliefs affect gender equality?
lead_paragraph: How do a culture’s or society’s values and beliefs affect gender equality?

headline: Robert Kraft Asks Judge to Suppress Video Evidence
abstract: “Florida resorted to the most drastic, invasive, indiscriminate spying conceivable by law enforcement,” lawyers for the Patriots owner contended.
lead_paragraph: Robert K. Kraft, the New England Patriots owner, has asked the judge overseeing his case on charges of solicitation of prostitution to suppress key evidence against him, including video that the police have said shows him receiving sex from a masseuse at a spa in Jupiter, Fla.

headline: In Profane Rant, Cuomo Aide Calls 3 Female Lawmakers ‘Idiots’
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'State Legislatures']

headline: Disney Bans Smoking at Parks in Florida and California
abstract: The company, which in 2015 banned smoking in its movies geared toward younger audiences, said Thursday it will close all theme park smoking areas on May 1.
lead_paragraph: On May 1, Disney parks in Florida and California will become smoke-free, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: ‘They’re Going to Boo Me.’ Jimmy Butler Prepares for His Return to Minnesota.
abstract: The rare N.B.A. star willing to lean into his role as a villain, Butler, briefly back in the city he scorned, is ready to absorb fans’ anger.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Butler knows what’s coming on Saturday night in Minneapolis. He understands, relishes and even encourages the looming prospect of the chilliest welcome any visiting N.B.A. player is bound to receive this season.

headline: The Plague Killing Frogs Everywhere Is Far Worse Than Scientists Thought
abstract: As a threat to wildlife, an amphibian fungus has become “the most deadly pathogen known to science.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, 41 scientists published the first worldwide analysis of a fungal outbreak that’s been wiping out frogs for decades. The devastation turns out to be far worse than anyone had previously realized.

headline: Review: A Magnificent Road to Ruin in ‘The Lehman Trilogy’
abstract: This three-hour-plus portrait of the creation and destruction of the house of Lehman, directed by Sam Mendes, is an endlessly absorbing epic tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, there is nothing. And in the end, there is — nothing, once again.

headline: Review: In New Batsheva Work, Dance It Once. Then Repeat With Variations.
abstract: Ohad Naharin’s “Venezuela,” at BAM, is a stark, nuanced work that moves with its own lucid flow.
lead_paragraph: Ohad Naharin’s “Venezuela” starts out mysteriously, but that’s not mysterious: Being enigmatic is his way. Dancers with their backs to the audience — already it’s a little perverse — inch ahead in tiny steps as their bodies lean quietly from side to side. A woman and then a man suddenly strike a pose: She raises an arm with a wilted wrist, her other hand on her waist, elbow out. His arm and leg strike out to the side. The music is a Gregorian chant.

headline: What Students Are Saying About: Leaving a Legacy, Fighting for a Cause and Looking at the Stars
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts — and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: If you read our Current Events Conversation regularly, you know that one thing we love to see is students talking to each other in the comments section. It’s an excellent way to practice your civil discourse skills, learn about people who are different from you and connect with other teenagers from all over the world.

headline: 14 Officers Indicted on Assault or Cover-Up Charges in Beating of Black Men
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Twelve current and two former officers are accused of beating four black men after a barroom dispute in Springfield, Mass., or participating in a cover-up of the assault.
lead_paragraph: A Massachusetts grand jury has indicted 12 current and two former officers of the Springfield Police Department who are accused of beating a group of four black men after a barroom dispute or participating in a cover-up of the assault.

abstract: An advocacy group suggests ways to get more young people of color into an important job.

abstract: Readers disagree about the value of “looking death in the eye.”

headline: Henry J. Stern, Whose Vast Urban Domain Was Green, Is Dead at 83
abstract: Only Robert Moses surpassed Mr. Stern, New York City’s longtime parks commissioner, in ensuring that a teeming population had places to breathe.
lead_paragraph: Henry J. Stern, who presided over New York City’s emerald empire for 15 years as commissioner of parks and recreation under two mayors, surpassing all but the Napoleonic Robert Moses in tenure and enhancements to the city’s greenswards and playgrounds, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Saturn’s Rings Are Sculpted by a Crew of Mini-Moons
abstract: Data from NASA’s Cassini spacecraft are helping to explain how Atlas, Daphnis, Epimetheus, Pan and Pandora are distinctive among Saturn’s many satellites.
lead_paragraph: Saturn has more than 60 moons, but a handful of them do more than spangle the planet’s skies.

headline: When Simplicity Can Be a Winemaking Virtue
abstract: Though these bottles are made in large quantities, the straightforward winemaking achieves a welcome sense of honesty in the glass.
lead_paragraph: Sweetness in wine can make people seem crazy.

headline: Mercurey: Exploring Burgundy’s Periphery for Accessible Reds
abstract: Burgundy is currently the most important wine region in the world for understanding how people think about wine. Its red wines are also delicious.
lead_paragraph: Few regions are as important to understanding contemporary trends in wine as Burgundy, not only in France but throughout the world.

headline: El Anatsui’s Monumental New Show Is an Act of Justice
abstract: A pilgrimage to Munich finds a resplendent tribute to the Ghanaian-born artist, and a fitting epitaph for the curator, Okwui Enwezor.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — I find it so hard to describe them: as vast, undulant tapestries, each one rippling and fluttering like a flag by the seashore? Or as heavy, defensive tessellations of metal, like the plate armor of soldiers in medieval Europe or Japan? As monumental mosaics, as landscapes of metallic bits and bobs? The wall-mounted sculptures of El Anatsui here at the Haus der Kunst cry out for metaphorical comparisons — but no metaphor ever seems enough to sum up these commanding artworks, each intricate enough to leave you gasping.

headline: A weekly update for new and expecting parents
abstract: Get the NYT Parenting newsletter for the latest news and guidance for parents.
lead_paragraph: Get the NYT Parenting newsletter for the latest news and guidance for parents.

headline: Lincoln Kirstein: A Modern Tastemaker With Some Iffy Taste
abstract: An art critic and dance critic talk about two Kirstein shows — and how his protean diversity left its mark on the arts, most productively on ballet.
lead_paragraph: The relentlessly busy life, aesthetic proclivities and multimedia achievements of Lincoln Kirstein — this country’s most catalytic balletomane — are in high relief right now in New York, thanks to two exhibitions, “Lincoln Kirstein’s Modern,” at the Museum of Modern Art, and “The Young and Evil” at David Zwirner in Chelsea.

headline: Give Up Owning a Car? An Urban Fantasy
abstract: Kara Swisher predicted a shift away from private vehicles. Two readers are dubious.

headline: Who’s Getting Rich When Uber, Slack and Other ‘Unicorns’ Go Public
abstract: Highly valued tech start-ups are going public this year, and their debuts promise to generate big paydays for employees and investors. Here are what some of their stakes are worth at their I.P.O.s.
lead_paragraph: Highly valued tech start-ups are going public this year, and their debuts promise to generate big paydays for employees and investors. Here are what some of their stakes are worth at their I.P.O.s.

headline: Meghan Markle and My Tabloid Obsession
abstract: She’s a Rorschach test for whoever happens to be reading and writing about her.
lead_paragraph: My weekly magazine ritual started in college, with People magazine, but I quickly grew bored of its articles. To get to the good dirt, you had to page past feel-good stories about small towns coming together and crossword puzzles that appeared to be written to make a very sleepy child feel good about herself.

headline: Barbecue, Opulent and Austere
abstract: There is no monolithic porterhouse at Paladar in East Harlem: Diversity is the mission, from beef blackened at the edges to dense little chicken hearts.
lead_paragraph: There is no monolithic porterhouse at Paladar in East Harlem: Diversity is the mission, from beef blackened at the edges to dense little chicken hearts.

headline: Churrasco That Rises Above at Paladar in East Harlem
abstract: The meat at this modest Brazilian pay-per-pound joint is scarcely adorned, tastes only of itself, salt and fire, and is worthy of eating cut after cut.
lead_paragraph: There they are, the racks of meat on skewers as long as harpoons, inexorably turning. This is churrasco, Brazilian barbecue, opulent and austere at once, the meat scarcely adorned and tasting only of itself, salt and fire.

headline: Spine-Chilling and Flesh-Crawling: The Latest Horror Fiction
abstract: There’s something for everyone here: 17th-century English witches, haunted portraits, Victorian ghost tales and a moldering Eastern European castle.
lead_paragraph: Great horror writing is more than cheap scares and bloody fingerprints. When it’s really good, horror can push you up against the hard questions of existence. Nothing clarifies your relationship to other people and the world around you, to your future and your past, quite like a chainsaw massacre. And yet physical pain is not the point. We’re spectators, after all, experiencing fear without actual danger. What we get from horror is an appreciation for human resilience, and the gobsmacked realization that it is a miracle anyone survives in this cruel world at all.

Their landlord was planning to do away with the key-fob system that allowed them entry into their buildings on the theory that lost fobs could wind up in the wrong hands and were now also relatively easy to duplicate.

headline: G.O.P. Cruelty Is a Pre-existing Condition
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Republicans just won’t stop trying to take away health care.
lead_paragraph: It’s already clear how the 2020 election campaign will be waged. Republicans will claim, falsely, that Democrats want to take away your hamburgers. Democrats will assert, truthfully, that Republicans want to take away your health care.

headline: Miriam Toews’s Mennonite Conscience
abstract: In her new book, “Women Talking,” the beloved Canadian novelist directs her gaze at the moral failings of the Protestant sect in which she was raised.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Miriam Toews woke up the other night, her heart racing. She wasn’t having another dream about her sister’s violent death, or her father’s, or the rapes suffered by the women at the center of her latest book, “Women Talking,” to be released April 2 in the United States. This night, her Mennonite conscience had found something far more mundane to worry over: Toews had promised the department store saleswoman who so kindly helped her pick out the right pants for her 83-year-old mother, Elvira, that she would send a complimentary email to her boss, and she’d forgotten.

headline: Luke Voit’s Blast Makes Yankees’ Opener a Breeze
abstract: Voit set the tone with a three-run homer and Masahiro Tanaka pitched the Yankees to an easy win over the Orioles to kick off a season of high hopes.
lead_paragraph: Glorious daydreams abound on opening day, when each team’s slate is clean and the season’s inevitable trials and tribulations haven’t yet piled up. But the images of winning a pennant and hoisting the World Series trophy are far more realistic for some — the 2019 Yankees included.

headline: ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ in the Time of Netflix

Is it acceptable to adapt a work that its author, who died in 2014, did not want to take to the big screen?

headline: The Taxman Is (Not) Coming After You

headline: Inside the Tensions at Carlos Ghosn’s Nissan
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Boards of Directors', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Once seen as a model of global cooperation, the Nissan-Renault alliance seethed with fear and rivalries, raising questions about its future.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was 2011, and Carlos Ghosn was preparing his automotive empire for its most ambitious phase yet. Under his plan, within five years, one of every 12 cars sold around the world would be made by Nissan of Japan. To achieve that goal and cut costs relentlessly, he said, Nissan would have to work closely with Renault, the French automaker he also controlled.

headline: Longing for an Internet Cleanse
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Philosophy', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Art', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: A small rebellion against the quickening of time.
lead_paragraph: The two most recent times I saw my friend Makoto Fujimura, he put a Kintsugi bowl in my hands. These ceramic bowls were 300 to 400 years old. But what made them special was that somewhere along the way they had broken into shards and were glued back together with a 15th-century technique using Japanese lacquer and gold.

headline: European Court Rules Against 9/11 Victims Seeking $1.6 Billion From Iran
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States International Relations', 'Immunity from Prosecution', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Assets, Frozen', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: At issue in the ruling is the post-World War II practice of keeping governments immune from lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A court in Luxembourg has ruled against a group of Sept. 11 victims in a novel lawsuit seeking $1.6 billion in Iranian assets, bringing to a head a long growing disagreement about a significant question of international law: Should governments be immune from lawsuits even when they are accused of responsibility for terrorist attacks?

headline: Disaster Relief Bill at an Impasse Over Puerto Rico Aid
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: Senate Democrats may block legislation proposed by their Republican counterparts that would allocate billions of dollars across the country, citing a push for more aid for Puerto Rico’s recovery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats next week may block legislation proposed by their Republican counterparts that would allocate billions of dollars for disaster recovery across the country, citing opposition from House Democrats and a push to add more aid to Puerto Rico’s slow efforts to recover from a pair of devastating hurricanes more than a year ago.

headline: Review: In ‘The Tragedy of Julius Caesar,’ the Political Thrill Is Gone

lead_paragraph: A Shakespeare play is like a Hallmark card. There is one for every occasion. When you have an audience embroiled in problems of governance — and since no one has thought to release the Mueller report in iambic pentameter — might as well pluck “Julius Caesar” off the shelf.

keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Religion and Belief', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Buddhism']

headline: Productivity Isn’t About Time Management. It’s About Attention Management.
abstract: “Time management” is not a solution — it’s actually part of the problem.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago during a break in a leadership class I was teaching, a manager named Michael walked up looking unsettled. His boss had told him he needed to be more productive, so he had spent a few hours analyzing how he spent his time. He had already cut his nonessential meetings. He couldn’t find any tasks to drop from his calendar. He didn’t see an obvious way to do them more efficiently.

lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The sweat had not yet dried on the brows of Gonzaga’s basketball players after they dispatched Baylor last weekend, but their gaze turned quickly to what lay ahead — a chance to rewrite last season’s ending.

Center here in Louisville caught their breath Thursday night after a classic duel between Purdue and Tennessee in the first game of the South Region doubleheader, No. 1 seed Virginia and No. 12 Oregon slogged through a tight, mediocre first half.

abstract: Between trade, taxes and the Federal Reserve, President Trump is getting what we wants in the economy. But it may not last.

headline: Finding Fraternity and Politics in Algerian Soccer
abstract: Fethi Sahraoui has been photographing young Algerians who rush to local stadiums for biweekly soccer matches and for a chance to be heard.
lead_paragraph: Arms raised high. Crowds united in song. Riot police armed with batons. These images could have been taken at political rallies or protests. But they weren’t. They were from soccer matches in northwestern Algeria.

headline: In a Crowded Syria Tent Camp, the Women and Children of ISIS Wait in Limbo
abstract: “I just want to go back to a normal life”: The Times visited a camp, swollen to breaking point, where the families of ISIS fighters are stuck.
lead_paragraph: AL HOL CAMP, Syria — She left the Netherlands to join the Islamic State in Syria, and married a fighter here. He was killed, so she married another, who got her pregnant before he was killed, too.

headline: Are My Allergies All in My Head?
abstract: Allergies exist. But emotional factors can make them better or worse.

headline: On Being an Outsider
abstract: The thrill of ‘otherness’ was less delightful to my children than it was to me.
lead_paragraph: Before I had any children of my own, I spent a decade and a half living in places where I was an outsider. While I never lost the feeling of estrangement that comes from missing basic cultural cues, for me this was a period of great liberation. I loved the freedom that being a stranger gave me. I loved the fact that people were unable to “place” me and that I was also largely free of preconceptions about them.

headline: The Races Are Virtual but the Running Is Real
abstract: Participants in virtual races run whenever they can, wherever they can, and say they still have some of the sense of being part of a crowd, even if they’re running alone.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday morning, Kate Silvester ran a 5K. She didn’t have to worry about where to park to get to the starting line in time: She just headed out to a biking and running path behind her house and onto a back road.

headline: They Let a Sick Inmate Die in a Van. Now They Won’t Pay His Family $650,000.
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Extradition', 'Privatization', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Vans']
abstract: The prisoner transport business has a poor safety record. Here’s how one company has dodged responsibility in the death of an inmate.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Smith spent almost 24 hours shackled in the back of a prison van — barely conscious and muttering incoherently — before he died there in 2011. A private company was hauling Mr. Smith, 48, to Florida from Kentucky to face a drug charge: possession of a single oxycodone pill.

headline: Airline Booking Hacks: What Works, and What Might Get You in Trouble
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Finding the lowest airfare has become a favorite frugal pastime, and there are websites to help you nail down cheap fares. Some strategies, however, are dicey.
lead_paragraph: Between bargain-shopping travelers and airlines flashing ephemeral prices, searching for the lowest airfares can feel like a game of cat and mouse. Sometimes, the game carries real-world risks, including the recent news that Lufthansa is suing a passenger who the airline contends intentionally skipped a flight leg using a largely prohibited budget-booking practice known as hidden city.

headline: Families Banter and Bicker Their Way Through Three New Novels
