lead_paragraph: LONDON — This week, as two members of Parliament interrupted a debate on Brexit to rib each other about the elite boarding schools they attended four decades ago, 23-year-old Eve Alcock looked on with deep disgust.

headline: ‘In Afghanistan, We Laugh Differently’
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: For a handful of teenage girls, robotics offered a reprieve from their violent, patriarchal country. Now they are back home, with the Taliban poised to gain power.
lead_paragraph: HERAT, Afghanistan — A 2017 wall calendar dangled from a nail over Kawsar Roshan’s bed on the otherwise blank wall of her room. “Best year for me” she had written, in curly script, above aerial photos of lakes and waterfalls. She drew a smiley-face next to her wobbly English letters.

headline: Italy’s Deal With China Signals a Shift as U.S. Influence Recedes
keywords: ['United States International Relations', '5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations']
abstract: Far from being isolated in Europe, the Italians say they are leading the expansion of new relations with China, and fully expect others to follow.
lead_paragraph: ROME — For decades, Italy felt the brunt of the Chinese economic juggernaut that the United States argues poses a threat to the financial and political future of the West.

headline: Ukrainians Vote, in Europe’s Only Country at War
abstract: Five years after a revolution, Ukrainians are less thankful for their new leaders than for the freedom to vote them out of power.
lead_paragraph: Under a campaign billboard for President Petro O. Poroshenko declaring “there are many candidates but one president,” Ukrainians picked through the meager selection — instant coffee, canned milk, bananas — on sale at a makeshift sidewalk stand in Kiev, emblematic of the country’s economic hardship.

headline: Celebrating ‘Platinum Week’ in Japan
abstract: An unprecedented 10-day holiday period offers visitors a once-in-a-generation travel opportunity.
lead_paragraph: In chronically overworked Japan, the Golden Week holiday period offers rare respite for the country’s work force. Each spring, from late April to early May, the country celebrates four nonconsecutive national holidays over a seven-day period.

headline: 50 Years of Affirmative Action: What Went Right, and What It Got Wrong
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties']
abstract: A look back through the decades shows the successes and challenges of a divisive social policy.
lead_paragraph: On cold mornings, Les Goodson shows up early outside the University Club, on a wealthy stretch of Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and races two panhandlers he has nicknamed Catman and Pimp-the-Baby for a warm spot in front of a steam vent. He launches into “Take Five” on his saxophone, leaving his case open for bills and coins.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Gen Z has its say. Amanda Hess on the college admissions scandal. Kids and room sharing. A woman who feels no pain. Adventurous, alone, attacked. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. For me, this was a week to get projects done. Spring cleaning. Replanting. Cleaning out the fridge. If you’ve been busy doing chores (or watching your N.C.A.A. bracket bust), you may have missed these great stories. Take a look.

headline: A Timeline of Key Supreme Court Cases on Affirmative Action
abstract: The Supreme Court has weighed in on affirmative action several times. Here are some key cases through the decades.
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court has weighed in on affirmative action in college admissions several times, helping shape the policy through the decades. Here are some of the key cases:

headline: Woman Kept Dozens of Immigrants in Home, Forcing Some to Work, U.S. Says
abstract: The F.B.I. found 19 adults and 14 children from Guatemala living in a woman’s home outside of Chicago. The woman was charged with two counts of forced labor.
lead_paragraph: An Illinois woman is facing federal charges of forced labor after the F.B.I. raided her home and discovered 33 Guatemalan immigrants, some of whom were made to work and pay thousands of dollars as a debt for helping them stay in the United States, the authorities said this week.

headline: Hotel Review: The Revolution Hotel, Boston
abstract: A budget hotel is long on camaraderie and short on creature comforts.
lead_paragraph: From $150, with discounts for students, artists and caretakers.

headline: The Rapture and the Real World: Mike Pompeo Blends Beliefs and Policy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Religion and Belief', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: America’s top diplomat stands out in the Trump administration for brazenly inserting his evangelical Christian beliefs into discussions of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Secretary of State Mike Pompeo sat down for an interview with the Christian Broadcasting Network in a hotel in Jerusalem earlier this month, he made a remark that was perhaps the most revelatory of any in his nearly one year in office.

headline: 2020 Democrats Love Small Donors. But Some Really Love Big Donors, Too.
abstract: Several 2020 presidential candidates are focused on attracting small donors to prove grass-roots appeal, but are also privately courting major donors whose money helps pay campaign bills.
lead_paragraph: Senator Cory Booker spun through a San Francisco fund-raiser hosted on Friday afternoon by high-tech titans and wealthy venture capitalists, including the investor Ron Conway. That evening, in New York, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand gathered donations at the Upper West Side home of Matthew Mallow, a vice chairman of the investment giant BlackRock.

headline: What Would Texas Be Without Buc-ee’s?
abstract: A convenience store chain is the through-line of America’s second-most sprawling state.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Ask any Texan and they’ll tell you: Buc-ee’s is no ordinary convenience store. Sure, it sells the usual gas, gum and candy. But most of its goods can’t be found in your average side-of-the-highway shop.

headline: Med Students Get an Extra Match on ‘Match Day’
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Careers and Professions', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Medical Schools']
abstract: Across the country, couples are escalating the day they learn where they will go for their residencies by using it as an opportunity to propose.
lead_paragraph: Match Day at the University of Mississippi Medical Center is always a big deal. It’s the day medical students in their final year learn where they will be doing their residencies for the next three to five years.

headline: D.E.A. Secretly Collected Bulk Records of Money-Counter Purchases
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Inspectors General', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A redaction error in an inspector general report brought to light another bulk-collection program ended in the aftermath of Edward Snowden’s leaks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Drug Enforcement Administration secretly collected data in bulk about Americans’ purchases of money-counting machines — and took steps to hide the effort from defendants and courts — before quietly shuttering the program in 2013 amid the uproar over the disclosures by the National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden, an inspector general report found.

headline: Why Are Female Runners Faster Than Ever?
abstract: A panel discussion with elite women runners the week before the Boston Marathon.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Protest at Gaza Fence Is Mostly Peaceful as Both Sides Urge Restraint
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Border Barriers', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Tens of thousands of Palestinians marked the first anniversary of protests that have frequently led to violence. Three Palestinians were killed.
lead_paragraph: NAHAL OZ, Israel — Tens of thousands of Palestinians returned to the borderland between Gaza and Israel on Saturday for a largely peaceful protest marking the first anniversary of demonstrations that have frequently led to violent clashes with Israeli troops.

headline: Assisted by StubHub and Beyoncé
abstract: The couple met through a dating app shortly after each had moved to Philadelphia from New York.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Regina Maree Myers and Joshua Alexander Kulick were married March 30 at the Loews Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Stacy Rigler officiated.

headline: Matt Gaetz Is a Congressman Liberals Love to Loathe. It’s All Part of the Plan.
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Gaetz came to Washington as the son of the Florida Senate president, with a reputation for deal making. His incendiary antics have put that rap behind him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida came to Washington in 2017 with a reputation for bipartisan deal-cutting in the State Legislature — then spent a year idling behind the slow-moving minivans in the House Republican Conference like a Mustang stuck in traffic.

headline: As Venezuelan Economy Unravels, Maduro Opponents Hope Downturn Will Topple Him
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The prolonged national blackout this month pushed the country closer to the brink of economic collapse. Inflation is expected reach 51 million percent this year.
lead_paragraph: PUERTO ORDAZ, Venezuela — President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela drove himself to an ailing iron plant this month to tout its export capacity amid tightening American sanctions.

headline: Can My Co-op Really Ban Young Children From the Backyard?
abstract: Co-ops cannot discriminate against any shareholder. But they also have to protect the building.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am a shareholder in a small, white-glove Upper East Side co-op. The board recently refurbished the common area in the backyard and purchased outdoor furniture. New rules permit the children of shareholders who are 16 and older to sit in the yard during appropriate hours and enjoy the garden in a quiet manner. The younger children of shareholders are prohibited from ever setting foot in the yard, even under parental supervision. Irrespective of co-op rules, may the board treat residents differently this way?

headline: Janet Jackson and Stevie Nicks Speak Up for Women at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
abstract: The institution’s 34th annual induction ceremony in Brooklyn was a tame affair dominated by men: Radiohead, the Cure, Def Leppard, Roxy Music and the Zombies.
lead_paragraph: For the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame’s class of 2019, pop stardom is, roughly, a tale of two genders: Powerful women who stand proudly alone, and well-behaved groups of men with too many bass players to mention.

headline: Afghan National Security Chief Is Sidelined in His Own War
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As the Americans negotiate with the Taliban directly, they are shunning Afghanistan’s national security adviser — and perhaps the president as well.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The longtime motto of the American-led mission in Afghanistan that it stands “shona ba shona,” or shoulder to shoulder, with its Afghan ally no longer applies to that ally’s national security adviser.

headline: 31 Pastas That Celebrate Spring
abstract: Springtime spaghetti carbonara, pasta primavera, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: We’re excited about fresh, verdant ingredients to toss with our favorite pastas. Make springtime spaghetti carbonara (above), lemony pasta with zucchini and fresh herbs, or any of the recipes in the collection below.

headline: What’s the Secret to Reaching 111? ‘Avoid Dying,’ but ‘Porridge Is Helpful’
abstract: Alfred Smith and Bob Weighton were both born on March 29, 1908. But Britain’s oldest men say they’re as puzzled as anyone about the secret to longevity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Alfred Smith and Bob Weighton were born, Edward VII was king of Britain. They have lived through two world wars, more than 20 prime ministers and the entire rule of Britain’s longest-reigning monarch. They also saw Britain join the predecessor of the European Union — a bloc it was supposed to leave on Friday, the day both men turned 111.

headline: Are You ‘Virtue Signaling’?
abstract: Probably. But that doesn’t mean your outrage is inauthentic.
lead_paragraph: Expressions of moral outrage are playing a prominent role in contemporary debates about issues like sexual assault, immigration and police brutality. In response, there have been criticisms of expressions of outrage as mere “virtue signaling” — feigned righteousness intended to make the speaker appear superior by condemning others.

headline: The Irish Border Is a Scar
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Could Brexit reignite the Troubles in Northern Ireland?
lead_paragraph: My friend Sean, like a lot of people in Ireland, tells a good story. He used to work for the National Roads Authority; they couldn’t call it the Irish Roads Authority, he liked to joke, because the abbreviation “I.R.A.” was already taken.

headline: High School Doesn’t Have to Be Boring
abstract: Debate, drama and other extracurriculars provide the excitement many classrooms lack. And they can help overhaul the system.
lead_paragraph: When you ask American teenagers to pick a single word to describe how they feel in school, the most common choice is “bored.” The institutions where they spend many of their waking hours, they’ll tell you, are lacking in rigor, relevance, or both.

headline: Beto O’Rourke, Praising Immigration, Kicks Off Presidential Campaign in El Paso
abstract: Mr. O’Rourke officially launched his campaign near the border with Mexico. His downtown rally came amid extraordinary discord over immigration.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Beto O’Rourke officially kicked off his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination Saturday morning, quoting the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., raising populist themes and praising the way immigration has enriched El Paso and the nation.

headline: Joe Biden Says He Did Not Act Inappropriately With Lucy Flores
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former vice president, accused by Ms. Flores, a Nevada Democrat, of kissing and touching her, did acknowledge ‘expressions of affection’ on campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., under pressure to respond to allegations that he touched and kissed a former Nevada assemblywoman, Lucy Flores, went on the defensive Sunday morning with a sweeping statement saying he did not believe he acted inappropriately but acknowledging that he had made “expressions of affection” during his years on the campaign trail.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, this acrostic is just my type.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC —  Happy spring, everybody! I know the sentiment is belated but I’m still throwing it out there. Today’s excerpt is from a book by a New York City luminary, Francine Prose, called “Reading Like a Writer: A Guide for People Who Love Books and for Those Who Want to Write Them.”

headline: Spring Brings Surge of Migrants, Stretching Border Facilities Far Beyond Capacity
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Migration along the southern border typically increases in the spring, but authorities said the current numbers have reached “unmanageable” levels.
lead_paragraph: [Read the latest edition of Crossing the Border,  a limited-run newsletter about life where the United States and Mexico meet. Sign up here to receive the next issue in your inbox.]

headline: Keeping Up With the Kardashian Cash Flow
abstract: Are Kourtney, Kim, Khloé, Kendall and Kylie America’s savviest C.E.O.s?
lead_paragraph: Even when bad things happen to the Kardashians, they still make money.

headline: Trump’s Order to Open Arctic Waters to Oil Drilling Was Unlawful, Federal Judge Finds
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The decision has broad implications for Mr. Trump’s effort to push drilling across the American coastline and on public lands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a major legal blow to President Trump’s push to expand offshore oil and gas development, a federal judge ruled that an executive order by Mr. Trump that lifted an Obama-era ban on oil and gas drilling in the Arctic Ocean and parts of the North Atlantic coast was unlawful.

headline: How Pain Tolerance and Anxiety Seem to Be Connected
abstract: An article about the case of a woman who feels little pain or anxiety raised many questions, such as: Do low-anxiety people seem to feel less pain?
lead_paragraph: An article this week about Jo Cameron, who has lived for 71 years without experiencing pain or anxiety because she has a rare genetic mutation, prompted questions from New York Times readers.

headline: The Week in Business: The Sackler Family Gets Sued, and Theresa May’s Darkest Hour
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Christchurch, New Zealand, Attack (March 2019)', 'Opioids and Opiates', 'Web-Original Programming', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Plus, Apple makes TV shows now, and China trade talks pick up steam.
lead_paragraph: Here’s your checklist of everything to know in business and tech for the coming week, so you can feel up-to-date and well-rounded even if all you want to talk about is Meghan Markle’s baby. (Any day now!) Enjoy the rest of your weekend.

headline: Inside America’s Black Box: A Rare Look at the Violence of Incarceration
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Would we fix our prisons if we could see what happens inside them?
lead_paragraph: The contraband is scary enough: Homemade knives with grips whittled to fit particular hands. Homemade machetes. And homemade armor, with books and magazines for padding.

headline: A Leonardo Made a $450 Million Splash. Now There’s No Sign of It.
abstract: Since a Saudi royal, most likely the crown prince, paid $450 million for “Salvator Mundi,” it has vanished from view, and museums hoping to show it say they don’t know where it is.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — The Louvre Abu Dhabi might seem to have all you could ask for in a world-class museum. Its acclaimed design shades its galleries under a vast dome that appears to hover over the waters of the Persian Gulf. Inside are works by Rembrandt and Vermeer, Monet and van Gogh, Mondrian and Basquiat.

headline: Solving the Problems of Rural America
abstract: Readers react to Paul Krugman’s statement that “nobody knows how to reverse” the economic decline of the heartland.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Trump Boom
keywords: ['Taxation', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Shelters', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: At least corporate accountants are having some fun.
lead_paragraph: So far, Donald Trump has passed only one significant piece of legislation: the 2017 tax cut. It was, to be fair, a pretty big deal: corporations, the principal beneficiaries, have already saved more than $150 billion, and over the course of a decade the tax cut will probably increase the budget deficit by more than $2 trillion.

headline: Longtime N.H.L. Powers Adjust to the View From the Bottom
abstract: The Kings, the Ducks and the Blackhawks dominated the Western Conference in the past 10 years. But they have been left behind as the league has evolved.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From 2009 to 2018, the Los Angeles Kings, the Anaheim Ducks and the Chicago Blackhawks combined for 10 trips to the Western Conference finals and five Stanley Cups.

headline: The Story Behind a 2,600-Year-Old Seal
abstract: Who was Natan-Melech, the king’s servant?
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli archaeologist Yuval Gadot is not a mushy guy. But in October, when he pulled a 2,600-year-old seal impression out of the ground in the Givati Parking Lot excavation in the City of David, he was “very emotional.”

headline: Santa Anita’s Reopening Day Ends With a Feeling of Relief
abstract: A string of horse deaths had forced the famed track to close and the sport to ponder its future. Friday’s card was raced without problems.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — The mood was tense on Friday at Santa Anita Park, one of the grandest venues in horse racing, as the usually mellow track in Los Angeles County reopened after a nearly monthlong shutdown. Twenty-two horses had died on the grounds over 11 weeks.

headline: We’re All Stuck Inside George and Kellyanne’s Marriage
abstract: Are we watching a life partnership fracture on Twitter, a casualty of Donald Trump?
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, shortly after Attorney General William Barr had released his no collusion/maybe obstruction summary of Robert Mueller’s report, I spotted George Conway wandering out of the National Zoo, in Northwest Washington.

headline: Rwanda’s Children of Rape Have Come of Age
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes', 'Hutu Tribe', 'Tutsi Tribe', 'Women and Girls', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Twenty-five years after the genocide, its effects are shaping a new generation.
lead_paragraph: What are the effects of being born of rape in the name of genocide? How are mothers who survived this brutal violence in Rwanda dealing with the trauma and complexities of their lives and the long-lasting, multigenerational impact of what was done to them?

headline: What Happens When Women Stop Leading Like Men
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Jacinda Ardern, Nancy Pelosi and the power of female grace.
lead_paragraph: It has been another bad inning for male leadership. Besides the hourly flatulence of Trumpian twitterings and the addition of Brazil’s Bolsonaro to the confederacy of bullyboy power, we have been treated to a second wave of masculine mayhem. The reputations of the Patriots owner Robert Kraft, R. Kelly, the philanthropist Michael Steinhardt and even the sainted co-founder of the Southern Poverty Law Center, Morris Dees, are the latest to circle the drain. As Harvard’s Cornel West recently observed to Anderson Cooper, “The brothers are just out of control.”

headline: Can an Archaeological Dig Change the Future of Jerusalem?
abstract: The City of David is being unearthed on land that much of the world does not believe belongs to Israel.
lead_paragraph: The City of David is being unearthed on land that much of the world does not believe belongs to Israel.

headline: The Best Restaurant if You’re Over 50
abstract: It’s not just sex and sleep that change as you age. It’s supper.
lead_paragraph: [Get Frank Bruni’s exclusive commentary every week. Sign up for his newsletter.]

headline: The $70,000-a-Year Minimum Wage
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Small Business']
abstract: A small Seattle company shows that capitalism can have a heart.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Staff members gasped four years ago when Dan Price gathered the 120 employees at Gravity Payments, the company he had founded with his brother, and told them he was raising everyone’s salary to a minimum of $70,000, partly by slashing his own $1.1 million pay to the same level.

headline: How Much Should You Know About Your Therapist’s Life?
abstract: In today’s world, it’s impossible for any professional to be a blank slate. Maybe that’s not such a bad thing.
lead_paragraph: When I was starting out as a therapist, a colleague told me what was intended to be a cautionary tale. After suffering a series of miscarriages, she was in a Starbucks when her doctor called with the news that her pregnancy wasn’t viable. Standing at the counter, she burst into heaving sobs. A patient happened to walk in, saw her hysterically crying therapist, walked out the door, canceled her next appointment and never went back to her.

headline: In Match Play, Rory McIlroy Melts Down Early, and Tiger Woods Is Stunned Late
abstract: A comedy of bad shots cost McIlroy in his match against Woods and led to his sulking off after he lost the match on No. 17. Woods then lost to Lucas Bjerregaard.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Rory McIlroy never trailed in his first three matches at Austin Country Club, advancing to the round of 16 at the World Golf Championships match-play event without having to play the 17th or 18th holes. He was looking to extend his front-running ways in an elimination match against Tiger Woods, whose superlative career has been a sucker pin that McIlroy recently decided to stop taking dogged aim at.

headline: Trump’s Circus Maximus
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: King Donald’s subjects came from the rivers to bend the knee to their victorious Vulgarian.
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — It was going to be epic, like those Roman triumph celebrations where the generals would ride in on a chariot decorated with gold and ivory, so drunk on power that a slave would have to walk behind, holding a wreath over the general’s head and whispering in his ear, “Remember you are mortal.”

headline: Jussie Smollett Charges Were Dropped Because Conviction Was Uncertain, Prosecutor Says
abstract: In an op-ed, Kim Foxx, the Cook County state’s attorney, said she welcomed an “outside, nonpolitical review” of how her office handled the Jussie Smollett case.
lead_paragraph: The prosecutor whose office dropped disorderly conduct charges against the actor Jussie Smollett defended the decision, saying her office was uncertain it had enough evidence to gain a conviction and wanted to focus on bigger crime in Chicago, she wrote in an op-ed.

headline: At the Miami Open, It’s Ashleigh Barty’s Turn for a Title
abstract: The Australian beat Karolina Pliskova for her most significant victory, showing the promise of many more. She also became the 14th different WTA champion this year in 14 events.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — Another week on the 2019 tennis circuit, another different champion.

headline: The Mick Mulvaney Presidency
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: How an imaginary version of the Trump administration might make the real one lose in 2020.
lead_paragraph: This should have been one of the best weeks of Donald Trump’s presidency — a week when the shadow of impeachment lifted, when his fiercest critics were dramatically wrong-footed, when the NO COLLUSION! tweets suddenly came with a certified-by-Robert-Mueller stamp.

headline: The Secret Death Toll of America’s Drones
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Trump is making it harder to know how many civilians the government kills by remote control.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon says American airstrikes in Somalia have killed no civilians since President Trump accelerated attacks against Shabab militants there two years ago.

headline: New York’s Best Schools Need to Do Better
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Equal Educational Opportunities']
abstract: Yet again, the paucity of black and Latino students admitted to New York City’s elite public high schools is cause for alarm, and action.
lead_paragraph: The news that just seven black students were offered admission to Stuyvesant High School, the most celebrated public school in New York City, is an embarrassment.

headline: To the Type-A Person Having a Meltdown
abstract: If you’re not perfect, you’re worthless. I know the feeling.
lead_paragraph: Put down your phone and Post-it Notes for just a minute. I know you’re busy rewriting your to-do list in your head, first chronologically and then in order of task magnitude and then visually like a pie chart with different colors for each slice of pie according to how long each thing will take, but you can spare a little time.

headline: It’s Dangerous to Be a Boy
abstract: They smoke more, fight more and are far more likely to die young than girls. But their tendency to violence isn’t innate.
lead_paragraph: Early in my first go at being a father, I was hijacked by ancient impulses. Our family lived in a rowhouse neighborhood in Philadelphia, and right down the street was a small playground where gangs of boys gathered for games of stickball and basketball. My son loved playing sports. But he was unprepared for what developed as his friends grew older.

headline: Why Are We Still Slaughtering the American Bison?
abstract: Restoring herds to Native American land after 150 years would be a simple reparation for the country to make. But the cattle industry won’t allow it.
lead_paragraph: In a 120-acre pasture on an Indian reservation in northeastern Montana, five prime examples of America’s national mammal rumble and snort. They shake their enormous heads and use them to plow aside the snow to get to their feed. In the night, I like to think, they put those shaggy heads together to ruminate on the weird politics of the American West and blast clouds of exhausted air out their shiny nostrils.

headline: Rolling Stones Postpone Tour, Citing Mick Jagger’s Health Problems
abstract: Jagger’s doctors said he required medical treatment but expected he would make a full recovery. “I really hate letting you down like this,” he told fans.
lead_paragraph: The Rolling Stones said on Saturday that Mick Jagger required medical treatment for an unspecified health problem and that the band would postpone its spring tour in the United States and Canada.

headline: Pope Champions Migrants in Morocco, the Chief Departure Point for Europe
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Francis warned against indifference and silence on the crisis during a two-day visit to the North African nation.
lead_paragraph: RABAT, Morocco — Pope Francis called Saturday to mend the “great and deep wound” opened by the migration crisis, as he spoke during a visit to Morocco which has become the chief destination for sub-Saharan African migrants seeking to reach Europe.

headline: Getting Wind of an Issue Designed to Make Kids Laugh
abstract: The new humor-themed issue of The New York Times for Kids features writing on the science and philosophy of comedy — plus so many flatulence jokes they required their own page.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

headline: Take One for the Team
abstract: Andrew J. Ries selflessly sends us home with a puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — In case you missed the puzzle notes: Drop one letter from each set of shaded (or circled) letters in the grid to name a Major League Baseball team. The letters thus removed, in order from top to bottom, will spell an appropriate answer at 76-Down.

headline: Georgia Is Latest State to Pass Fetal Heartbeat Bill as Part of Growing Trend
abstract: The American Civil Liberties Union vowed to sue if the bill is signed into law. The courts have blocked similar efforts in other states.
lead_paragraph: Tensions over a growing movement to ban abortion after a fetal heartbeat can be detected intensified this week as lawmakers in Georgia passed a bill that stands to become one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis, Former Knicks Star, Is Accused of Sexual Assault
abstract: Porzingis, traded to the Dallas Mavericks in January, has been accused of sexually assaulting a woman at his home last season while he was with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: Kristaps Porzingis of the Dallas Mavericks is under investigation by the New York Police Department after a recent accusation that he sexually assaulted a woman last season while he was playing for the Knicks, according to two people familiar with the case who were not authorized to discuss it publicly.

headline: Yankees’ Offense Wakes Up Too Late in Loss to Orioles
abstract: The debut of James Paxton, the talented left-handed pitcher acquired in the off-season, was marred by too many mistakes and too few runs.
lead_paragraph: After another playoff appearance that did not end with a World Series title, the Yankees pinpointed their pitching staff as an area for improvement. They threw money at relief pitchers Adam Ottavino and Zack Britton, and at C.C. Sabathia and J.A. Happ, two veteran starting pitchers.

headline: ‘Living the Dream’: Pete Alonso Powers the Mets Past the Nationals
abstract: Alonso, in his second major league game, was 3 for 4 at the plate with two R.B.I. and another run scored. He was also a pleasant surprise on defense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Pete Alonso, the Mets’ first baseman, collected his first hit as a major leaguer on opening day, his general manager, Brodie Van Wagenen, congratulated him, and encouraged him to do better than a soft single to center.

headline: Zuzana Caputova Is Elected Slovakia’s First Female President
keywords: ['Elections', 'Women and Girls', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Riding a wave of popular discontent over widespread corruption, she vowed to return a sense of decency to the country’s often toxic political climate.
lead_paragraph: In a stunning rebuke of Slovakia’s populist governing party, Zuzana Caputova — a 45-year-old lawyer, activist and political newcomer — was elected Saturday as the nation’s first female president.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Jeff Bezos’ security consultant accused the Saudi government of gaining unauthorized access to the Amazon chief executive’s phone, as part of an effort to harm the world’s richest man.

headline: Trump Turns U.S. Policy in Central America on Its Head
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Gangs', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: His plan to cut aid to Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador is “shooting yourself in the foot,” said one human rights worker. Mexico has urged more funding for development.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — President Trump’s plan to cut off aid to three Central American countries for failing to stop the flow of migrants toward the United States breaks with years of conventional wisdom in Washington that the best way to halt migration is to attack its root causes.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg’s Call to Regulate Facebook, Explained
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Political Advertising', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Here’s why the Facebook chief executive invited Congress to regulate his company in a post on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has faced months of scrutiny for a litany of ills, from spreading misinformation to not properly protecting its users’ data to allowing foreign meddling in elections.

headline: College Student Samantha Josephson Found Dead After She Got Into a Car She Mistook for Her Uber, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Nathaniel D. Rowland, 24, was arrested in connection with the death of Samantha Josephson, 21, in South Carolina. The authorities did not disclose a motive or how she died.
lead_paragraph: The police in Columbia, S.C., arrested a man on Saturday in connection with the killing of a 21-year-old college student who was last seen early Friday before she apparently got into a car that she mistook for an Uber she had called, the authorities said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Britons United by Lost Hope, if Nothing Else
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 31, 2019.
lead_paragraph: “I’m wondering: What does more damage? Leaving without a deal? Or the total annihilation of faith in democracy?”

headline: No. 3 Texas Tech Upsets No. 1 Gonzaga for First Trip to Final Four
abstract: The Red Raiders’ stifling defense in the second half kept the game just out of reach for the Zags until it was too late.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Texas Tech men’s basketball team carries around a mantra like a chip on its shoulder: The secret’s in the dirt. It is a particularly appealing message — that success is usually found by getting your hands in the muck — especially to the ears of basketball mutts and vagabonds, and a star whose own father questioned why he would want to stay home in Lubbock.

headline: Jennifer Weissman, Nicholas Jette
abstract: The couple met in 2015 at a cocktail bar in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Nicole Weissman and Nicholas Edward Jette were married March 30 at the Four Seasons in Washington. Rabbi Shira Stutman officiated.

lead_paragraph: Jennifer Adams Hagan and Jeffrey Adam Humenansky were married March 30 at the Inn at Rancho Santa Fe, a resort and spa in San Diego. The Rev. Cole Floyd, a Baptist minister, officiated.

headline: Julie Keys, Andrew Heathfield
abstract: The couple met on a blind date while attending Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, from which they graduated.

Jesse Cohen, a friend of the groom, took part in the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: Rebecca Lauren Isaacson and Taylor Jordan Lustgarten are to be married March 31 at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz, the bride's maternal uncle, is to officiate.

lead_paragraph: Carter Martin Hahn and Mahlon Aaron Hartselle were married March 30 at the Martine Chaisson Gallery in New Orleans. Christine Wennekamp, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated, with Danielle Gard, another friend, taking part in the ceremony.

abstract: The couple met in 2014 through a dating website and were engaged three years later.

headline: Alexandra Armour, Joseph Stein
abstract: The couple met through mutual friends in Manhattan in January 2013.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Sarah Armour and Joseph Werner Stein were married March 30 at the Breakers Palm Beach in Palm Beach, Fla. Cory J. Ciklin, chief judge of the Florida Fourth District Court of Appeal, officiated.

headline: Virginia Fends Off Purdue and Naysayers to Reach the Final Four
abstract: The Cavaliers, a year after losing to a No. 16 seed in the first round, defeated the Boilermakers in overtime despite 42 points from Carsen Edwards.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — They could hear the whispers. One year after taking one of the most infamous defeats in N.C.A.A. tournament history by becoming the first No. 1 seed to lose to a No. 16 seed, the Virginia Cavaliers came back stronger than ever. They won the Atlantic Coast Conference regular season, and still there were skeptics. Earning the No. 1 seed in the South Region did little to quiet them.

headline: Amanda Lee, Derek Ju
abstract: The couple met while attending college in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Lee and Dr. Derek Guo Ju were married March 30 at the Bel-Air Bay Club in Pacific Palisades, Calif. Eric Schwartz, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: This Week’s Wedding Announcements
abstract: All of the weddings right here on one handy page for you.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Regina Maree Myers and Joshua Alexander Kulick met through a dating app Sept. 24, 2016 — shortly after each had moved to Philadelphia from New York — and went on a first date to a bar later that evening. He said he knew the first date would be different when she crossed the street and walked toward him.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Veep’ and ‘10 Things I Hate About You’
abstract: “Veep” returns for a final season on HBO. And “10 Things I Hate About You” turns 20.
lead_paragraph: “Veep” returns for a final season on HBO. And “10 Things I Hate About You” turns 20 years old.

headline: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Trump, Mueller and Barr Interpret the Final Report Very Differently
keywords: ['Television', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates']
abstract: Robert De Niro and Alec Baldwin returned to skewer the Mueller report on “Saturday Night Live,” while Sandra Oh hosted.
lead_paragraph: While the rest of the nation waits to learn if it will ever get to read the final report of the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III, and debates whether a recent letter written by Attorney General William P. Barr provided an adequate overview of the two-year investigation and its results, “Saturday Night Live” is here to tell you what it all means.

headline: New York State Budget Deal Brings Congestion Pricing, Plastic Bag Ban and Mansion Tax
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Taxation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Congestion Pricing', 'Bail', 'Plastic Bags']
abstract: The budget agreement, announced early Sunday, includes a new tax on high-end homes and a fee to drive into Manhattan’s busiest areas.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — After weeks of intraparty bickering, the New York State Legislature and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday signed off on a $175 billion budget that was wreathed with progressive initiatives, including changes to the cash bail system, a new tax on high-end homes and a groundbreaking plan to charge motorists to drive into Manhattan’s busiest stretches.

headline: Russia Ordered a Killing That Made No Sense. Then the Assassin Started Talking.
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: It turned out the killer of a Ukrainian electrician was working for Russian intelligence agents.
lead_paragraph: RIVNE, Ukraine — The target lived on the sixth floor of a cheerless, salmon-colored building on Vidinska Street, across from a thicket of weeping willows. Oleg Smorodinov found him there, rented a small apartment on the ground floor, and waited.

headline: The Legend of Zion
abstract: The tales of Zion Williamson’s feats did not begin when he arrived at Duke. They probably won’t end when he heads to the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Zion Williamson’s legend grows with every game, with each new thundering dunk and every stunning new feat of elevation. It has been this way for several years now, with Williamson the featured actor in a growing collection of viral clips that show a player with the skills to outrun almost anyone, to catch almost anything, to challenge almost anybody. Even his lowest moments — the sneaker that couldn’t hold him, the injured knee that cost him five games — have somehow morphed into highlights. But Williamson, an 18-year-old Duke freshman and the top prize in Tuesday night’s N.B.A. draft lottery, has been making memorable moments for years. A group of New York Times reporters tracked down some of the people who were present for a few of them, to ask them about the memories that stand out the most.

headline: Countries Want to Ban ‘Weaponized’ Social Media. What Would That Look Like?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Christchurch, New Zealand, Attack (March 2019)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship', 'Hate Crimes', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Artificial Intelligence']
abstract: No established democracies have ever come as close to applying such sweeping restrictions as Australia and New Zealand are considering in the wake of the Christchurch mosque shootings.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — What if live-streaming required a government permit, and videos could only be broadcast online after a seven-second delay?

headline: The Week in Books
abstract: Salman Rushdie on a “dazzling” debut novel, Bret Easton Ellis, the birth of American Modernism and more.
lead_paragraph: We take the weekend to highlight recent books coverage from The Times:

headline: The Criminal Investigations That Sprouted From Mueller
abstract: Federal prosecutors are pursuing a number of criminal inquiries that grew out of the investigation led by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are pursuing a number of criminal inquiries that grew out of the investigation led by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.

headline: Bret Easton Ellis Has Calmed Down. He Thinks You Should, Too.
abstract: In the 1980s and ’90s, the novelist was seen as a literary bad boy and the voice of his generation. Now 55, he’s about to publish his first book in nine years.
lead_paragraph: Bret Easton Ellis is no stranger to bad publicity. Ever since his 1985 debut, “Less Than Zero,” made him a literary sensation, his violently nihilistic fiction and his politically incorrect public persona have earned him as much fury as acclaim. And after three decades, five subsequent novels and a story collection, a podcast and more than a handful of media spats, Ellis still has more to say. On April 16, he will publish his first book in nine years — and his nonfiction debut — an essay collection called “White.” Not everybody is going to like it. He doesn’t care.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Loses Finance Director as She Struggles in Early Fund-Raising
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Money is a problem for the Democratic senator, who is likely to be substantially out-raised in the first quarter. And she’s not the fresh candidate anymore. But much time remains.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — On a Sunday afternoon earlier this month, Senator Elizabeth Warren began a swing through the South by proclaiming that she was running “a different type of campaign” — one that did not include high-dollar fund-raisers but was entirely reliant on grass-roots contributions.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: ‘Breaches Everywhere’: Flooding Bursts Midwest Levees, and Tough Questions Follow
abstract: Hundreds of miles of levees in the Midwest have been overwhelmed by the floods, leaving “Swiss cheese” infrastructure and reigniting a flood control debate.
lead_paragraph: CORNING, Mo. — The widespread, severe flooding in the Midwest over the last month has exposed the vulnerabilities in a levee system that is now so full of holes that many here ruefully describe it as “Swiss cheese.”

headline: The ‘Blue Prince of Montmartre,’ at 87, Still Rules Parisian Demimonde
abstract: Dressed habitually in blue, the silver-haired French icon Michou, the owner of Paris’s best-known cross-dressing cabaret, is a showman from a bygone era who still attracts adoring crowds.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The man in blue — azure suit, blue-tinted glasses and blue shoes — stepped onto the tiny stage of Paris’s best-known drag cabaret, and flashed a wide smile at the crowd.

headline: Why Courtrooms Are Kryptonite for Alex Jones
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Shock jocks lose their power when forced to tell the truth, the whole truth.
lead_paragraph: Nothing like a three-hour deposition under oath to turn an excitable conspiracy theorist into a man subdued, deferential and humbled. That’s the Alex Jones who the world met for the first time on Friday, when attorneys for families of the victims of a school shooting posted his deposition online.

headline: How We Hang Out at Work Together Online Now
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Instagram is for vacations. Facebook is for families. But TikTok takes us into the classrooms, airplanes, firehouses and fast-food franchises of our real lives.
lead_paragraph: Ever seen someone flip a coin with a forklift? Just place the coin on a hard, smooth surface. Lower the tip of the blade onto it, about halfway across the coin, leaving a bit of pressure, and ever so gently rake it back. The edge of the coin will catch, sending it flying up and over, maybe even onto the fork itself. It takes some practice.

headline: Brexit, Offshore Drilling, N.C.A.A.: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: North Korea Calls Raid at Its Embassy in Spain a ‘Terrorist Attack’
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'International Relations']
abstract: After the break-in at its embassy in Madrid last month, North Korea said it was monitoring reports that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been involved.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Sunday that a break-in and robbery at its embassy in Spain last month was “a grave terrorist attack” and a “flagrant violation of international law,” calling on Madrid to conduct a thorough and fair investigation of the mysterious incident.

headline: Afghan Vice President Survives Attack on Convoy
abstract: Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum had predicted that the Taliban would set an ambush for him, and they did, killing at least one of his bodyguards.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban ambushed a convoy escorting the vice president of Afghanistan, killing at least one of his bodyguards, Afghan officials said Sunday. The vice president, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, survived.

headline: No Joke: Ukraine TV Comedian Wins Election’s First Round
abstract: Voters crowded into polling stations in a presidential race in which a leading candidate was a 41-year-old who plays a president on television.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — A Ukrainian comedian who plays an accidental president on television delivered a walloping rebuke to the country’s political class in the presidential election on Sunday by emerging first in a crowded field of candidates, exit polls indicated.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Butternut squash and green curry, chipotle chicken pozole, or pasta alla vodka: Eat deliciously.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I wanted to make Trini-Chinese chicken (above) for the family, but one of the kids doesn’t eat chicken anymore. I thought maybe I’d try it with thin pork chops instead, grill them hard, paint them with sauce. But the other kid shook her head. “Lamb,” she said. “And can you make it with ground? Like ground lamb?”

headline: ‘Race-Biased Dragnet’: DNA From 360 Black Men Was Collected to Solve Vetrano Murder, Defense Lawyers Say
keywords: ['Racial Profiling', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Forensic Science', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes']

headline: Trump Administration Defends Plan to Close the Border, Telling Democrats, ‘We Told You So’
abstract: The president and his aides have become emboldened as border crossings surge.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, defended President Trump’s threat to end assistance to three Central American countries and to close parts of the United States border with Mexico next week, saying on Sunday that it would take “something dramatic” to prevent Mr. Trump from carrying out that plan.

headline: David White, Hitmaker With Danny and the Juniors, Dies at 79
abstract: He co-wrote the No. 1 hit “At the Hop” and wrote its follow-up, “Rock and Roll Is Here to Stay.” He later helped write hits for Lesley Gore and others.
lead_paragraph: David White, who formed the doo-wop quartet Danny and the Juniors in the mid-1950s, co-wrote their No. 1 hit “At the Hop” and composed their successful follow-up, “Rock and Roll Is Here to Stay,” died on March 16 in Las Vegas. He was 79.

headline: He Says He Found a Souvenir From the ’60s: The Stage at Woodstock
abstract: Steve Gold returned to a summer bungalow compound and found what he says was the stage from the 1969 Woodstock festival.

keywords: ['Extortion and Blackmail', 'Basketball (College)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: The celebrity lawyer and Trump foil faces federal extortion and financial fraud charges. He seems to be trying the case in the court of public opinion.
lead_paragraph: Just after making bail last Monday, the celebrity lawyer Michael Avenatti did what he had always done in the swirl of a hot story. He called a reporter.

headline: The Spice Rack Can Wait
abstract: A reader recalls dealing with down time between jobs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Keeping Up With the Kardashians’ Returns With Its New Star … Kanye West?
abstract: As the KUWTK trailer promises, Mr. Kim Kardashian is ready to share his feelings with you.
lead_paragraph: For the return of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” this weekend, we spoke with each of the five Kardashian-Jenner sisters — that’s Kourtney, Kim, and Khloé Kardashian, and Kendall and Kylie Jenner — about their entwined and individual businesses.

headline: Inside ISIS’ Former Capital: The Forgotten People of Raqqa
abstract: We went back to Raqqa, which was liberated more than a year and a half ago, to see how people were getting by. We saw Syrians dancing to celebrate the final battle against ISIS. But destruction is still all around and progress is slow. The fear now is that frustration could breed radicalization once again.
lead_paragraph: We went back to Raqqa, which was liberated more than a year and a half ago, to see how people were getting by. We saw Syrians dancing to celebrate the final battle against ISIS. But destruction is still all around and progress is slow. The fear now is that frustration could breed radicalization once again.

headline: Freed From ISIS, Syrians Struggle to Rebuild Raqqa
abstract: The Syrian city was liberated from the Islamic State more than a year and a half ago, but rebuilding is slow and hope is fading.
lead_paragraph: The liberation of Raqqa was a powerful blow to the Islamic State, which used the Syrian city as its capital.

headline: Political Handlers With Trump Ties Take Their Election Playbooks to Africa
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Consultants', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: American campaign consultants, including one mentored by Paul Manafort, are increasingly being hired by African candidates to help them win at the polls in still fragile democracies.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — When a Nigerian presidential candidate landed in the United States in January after years of being subject to a visa ban because of corruption allegations, he had a team of Western consultants and lobbyists to thank for the warm American welcome.

headline: Homage to a Dying Breed: Stick-Shift Cars
abstract: Readers describe the joys of a manual transmission and some benefits: harder to text while driving and a deterrent for car thieves.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: A ‘Twilight Zone’ Trying to Find Its Dimension
abstract: Jordan Peele’s reworking of the spooky classic is sleek and well-made, but it’s still looking for its voice.
lead_paragraph: When Rod Serling opened “The Twilight Zone” for business in 1959, it was a single, specific location. He defined it, in his signature Professor Spooky voice-over, as a place between light and shadow, science and superstition — you know the drill.

headline: For High Schoolers Only
abstract: We invite students to submit a letter in response to a recent article, and we’ll publish some of our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Once again, we are holding a letter-writing competition for high school students. We invite you to submit a letter to the editor in response to a Times news article, editorial, column or Op-Ed in the last few days. We will publish a selection of our favorites.

headline: Kenneth Gibson, 86, Dies; Newark Mayor Broke Race Barrier in Northeast
abstract: He pledged to make Newark a model city, saying, “If we solve the urban problem here, we can export our solution to other areas.”
lead_paragraph: Kenneth A. Gibson, who became the first black mayor of a major Northeastern city when Newark voters, still recovering from racial rioting three years earlier, elected him in 1970 to the first of four terms, died on Friday in West Orange, N.J. He was 86.

headline: Review: The Met Makes a Case for Mozart’s Least-Loved Opera
abstract: The fiercely empathetic Joyce DiDonato leads a well-sung revival of “La Clemenza di Tito.” If only the production lived up to its cast.
lead_paragraph: “La Clemenza di Tito,” Mozart’s least-loved opera, returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday evening to an auditorium yawning with empty seats.

headline: Where Prisoners Can Lock Their Cells, and Guards Are Told to Knock
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Privacy', 'Laptop Computers', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: As part of a strategy to improve confinement conditions and boost rehabilitation, a prison in Wales allows inmates laptops and the ability to lock their cells for privacy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For two years, inmates at a prison in Wales have been allowed to lock their cells from the inside — for privacy. Guards have been expected to follow a “knock first” policy before entering. The detainees have had access to laptops, through which they can order meals.

headline: Italian Minister Pans Hit Song by an Immigrant’s Son
keywords: ['Music', 'Italian Language', 'Politics and Government', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Interior Minister Matteo Salvini of the anti-immigrant League party was not a fan of the Italian-language rap tune with a Middle Eastern flavor that won a song contest.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Alessandro Mahmoud recently won a prestigious Italian song contest with his Italian-language rap tune “Money,” tinged with a Middle Eastern flavor. The lyrics recall how his Egyptian father “drank champagne during Ramadan” or beckoned him home from the playground with calls of “waladi habibi ta’aleena” — Arabic for “My son, my love, come here.”

headline: ‘Blurred Lines’ on Their Minds, Songwriters Create Nervously
keywords: ['Music', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: “I shouldn’t be thinking about legal precedent when I am trying to write a chorus,” a Beyoncé songwriter says, long after “Blurred Lines” led to a rise in plagiarism claims.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to be a songwriter in the pop world these days. Listeners rarely see your name. For anything but a giant hit, royalties from streaming are infinitesimal — and big tech companies seem to want to keep it that way.

headline: Brexit Is Messy. London’s Lawyers Are Cashing In.
abstract: Britain’s complicated exit from the European Union has rattled corporations around the world. And that means lawyers are pulling in clients and profit.
lead_paragraph: In any divorce, lawyers are the only surefire winners, and as Britain muddles through one of the biggest, messiest and most complicated breakups in economic history, the country’s top law firms are booming.

headline: A Jewish Councilman Who Said ‘Palestine Does Not Exist’ Loses Seat on Immigration Committee
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said the New York City councilman, Kalman Yeger, should lose his committee seat if he does not apologize.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Review: In ‘Mrs. Wilson,’ an Actress Uncovers Her Grandfather’s Lies
abstract: Ruth Wilson plays her own grandmother in a real-life story of secret agents, secret lives and multiple marriages on PBS’s “Masterpiece.”
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wilson lived an improbable, deceitful, destructive but undeniably intriguing life. An author of popular spy novels and a British secret agent himself in World War II, he married four women from the 1920s through the ’50s without bothering to divorce any of them. He managed to keep his four families mostly secret from each other during his lifetime, and his children (and many grandchildren) only got to know one another more than 40 years after he died.

headline: ‘Dumbo’ Falls Short of Box-Office Expectations but Still Comes in First
abstract: Tim Burton’s moody Disney remake sold $45 million in tickets in its first weekend. And Jordan Peele’s “Us” has crossed well over the $100 million mark.
lead_paragraph: “Dumbo” was no runt — but it was no mammoth hit, either.

headline: Roger Federer’s 101 Titles: By the Numbers
abstract: With a win over John Isner in Sunday's Miami Open final, Roger Federer now has 101 titles. He is eight short of matching Jimmy Connors for the most in the open era.
lead_paragraph: On March 2 in Dubai, Roger Federer joined Jimmy Connors as the only male tennis players in the open era with 100 career titles. With a victory on Sunday over John Isner in the final of the Miami Open, Federer, 37, is now eight titles behind Connors’s record of 109.

headline: Brexit, Indian Elections, the Kardashians: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Let us help you start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Who Is Lucy Flores, the Woman Accusing Joe Biden of Kissing Her?
abstract: Ms. Flores, 39, is a former Nevada state assemblywoman who lost campaigns to become the state’s lieutenant governor and to represent the Fourth District in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Flores, a former Nevada state assemblywoman, published an essay Friday in which she described Joseph R. Biden Jr. touching her inappropriately and kissing her on the head during a Democratic campaign rally in 2014, when he was vice president.

headline: Russia’s Military Mission Creep Advances to a New Front: Africa
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Arms Trade', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors']
abstract: In an influence campaign that is worrying the Pentagon, Russia’s weapons sales, military training programs and security agreements are growing across Africa.
lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Russia has been steadily expanding its military influence across Africa, alarming Western officials with increasing arms sales, security agreements and training programs for unstable countries or autocratic leaders.

headline: Review: Michelle Dorrance Happily Shares the Spotlight
abstract: In a stellar season at New York City Center, Ms. Dorrance’s tap troupe performed dances not only by her, but also by Brenda Bufalino and Bill Irwin.
lead_paragraph: Considering Michelle Dorrance’s virtuosity as a dancer — which in her medium, tap, is really a type of musician — perhaps it’s not surprising that she also sings and plays the bass. But it’s still a delight to see her do it all, switching seamlessly among roles, as she did in her company’s brief but stellar season at New York City Center.

headline: Migrants Moved Out of Holding Pen Under El Paso Bridge
abstract: The makeshift fenced enclosure was empty on Sunday, and officials said they were “in the process” of relocating migrants who were held there, including families with small children.
lead_paragraph: [Read the latest edition of Crossing the Border, a limited-run newsletter about life where the United States and Mexico meet. Sign up here to receive the next issue in your inbox.]

headline: A Bounce Goes Liverpool’s Way, but Rest Assured: There Will Be More
abstract: A chaotic moment against Tottenham sends Liverpool back above Manchester City at the top of the Premier League, but there is plenty of race still to be run.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Mohamed Salah’s name flashed up on the scoreboard. It rang out of Anfield’s public address system. It rolled and roiled down the stands and washed onto the field and into the sky, infused with jubilation and wonder, with relief and belief.

headline: Girls at North Carolina School Don’t Have to Wear Skirts, Judge Rules
abstract: A federal judge struck down a charter school policy that prohibited girls from wearing pants or shorts. “I hate wearing skirts,” a girl who opposed the rule wrote.
lead_paragraph: Three girls in North Carolina were fed up with a school policy prohibiting female students from wearing pants. Skirts, they said, were uncomfortable and restrictive. They wanted to be free to play at recess, do cartwheels with the boys and focus on learning in the classroom — not the position of their legs.

headline: Teenager Fatally Shot After Knocking on Wrong Apartment Door in Atlanta, Police Say
abstract: Omarian Banks, 19, thought he was outside an apartment he shared with his girlfriend, but a man inside confronted him and opened fire, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A teenager in Atlanta was fatally shot on Friday after knocking on the door of an apartment he mistakenly thought was the one he shared with his girlfriend, the authorities said.

headline: C.W.H.L. Folds, Leaving North America With One Women’s Hockey League
abstract: The Canadian league, which has been in operation since 2007, had some of the sport’s biggest stars. Many may be absorbed into the rival N.W.H.L.
lead_paragraph: In a sudden blow to women’s professional sports in North America, the Canadian Women’s Hockey League announced on Sunday that it would discontinue operations on May 1.

headline: Auburn Makes Its First Final Four by Beating Kentucky
abstract: The Tigers were playing without Chuma Okeke, but led by Bryce Brown and Jared Harper they were able to beat the Wildcats in overtime.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — On Saturday, Auburn Coach Bruce Pearl sat and listened as one after another of his top players acknowledged that neither Kansas nor North Carolina nor Kentucky had recruited them. No, they were not high school all-Americans; in fact, they were barely recruited at all.

abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.

abstract: The state’s plan to ban single-use plastic bags has become a talking point among city residents. Here’s what some had to say.

headline: UConn Tops Louisville and Reaches 12th Straight Final Four
abstract: Katie Lou Samuelson scored 29 points and second-seeded UConn held off No. 1 Louisville, 80-73, in the Albany Regional Final.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In the moments after Connecticut advanced to the Final Four on Sunday for the 12th year in a row, blue, yellow and orange confetti rode the waves of Coach Geno Auriemma’s undulating hair. The pieces dusted the shoulders of his blue suit jacket and hid inside the top of his unbuttoned shirt.

headline: These Silicon Valley Investors’ Bets May Pay Off
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Innovation']
abstract: A herd of technology public offerings this year and next year is set to anoint venture capital winners. Here are some of them.
lead_paragraph: Brian Chesky, chief executive of Airbnb, likes to tell the story of his early struggles to fund his home-sharing start-up. Many venture capitalists refused to meet with him, he said in an email. Some walked out in the middle of meetings.

headline: Joe Biden Scrambles to Stem Crisis After Lucy Flores’s Allegation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Sexual Harassment', '#MeToo Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former vice president’s attempt to rebut her story without dismissing it — or her — illustrated the #MeToo-era challenges that await a 76-year-old known his close physical contact with women.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. scrambled on Sunday to contain a quickly growing crisis for his likely presidential bid, putting forward several former female aides and allies to praise his treatment of women after Lucy Flores, a former Nevada legislator, accused Mr. Biden of kissing and touching her.

headline: The Kardashians Tell All About Jordyn Woods, Fyre Festival and Being Billionaires
abstract: Kourtney, Kim, Khloé, Kendall and Kylie are back, now with extra Kanye — because “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” is back on TV tonight.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, for the return of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians,” we talked to each of the Kardashian-Jenner family members about their businesses. All of the funniest parts are in the story itself and you should go read it right now!

headline: Tea Set
abstract: Joel Fagliano forges his own path on April Fools’ Day.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Some of you may have hoped for an April Fools’ Day trick as outrageous as the one from 2016 (as well as the Wordplay column that went with it), and some of you may be profoundly thankful that the crossword editors Will Shortz and Joel Fagliano have decided to go in a different direction this year.

headline: Roger Federer Outruns Time (and John Isner) Once Again to Win Miami Open
abstract: The win gave Federer his 101st singles title, and it left Isner limping with what he fears may be a stress fracture in his foot.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — No matter how smooth and imperious Roger Federer looked in the Miami Open final, whipping winners seemingly on demand and breaking big John Isner’s serve on four occasions, Federer knows all too well how fragile this all is as the shadows lengthen.

headline: Pope Francis Warns Trump About Walls After Morocco Visit
abstract: Urging compassion for migrants, the pope said those who close borders “will become prisoners of the walls that they build.”
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE PAPAL PLANE — Pope Francis, putting President Trump on notice, warned on Sunday that those who close borders “will become prisoners of the walls that they build.”

headline: 7 Takeaways From New York’s $175 Billion Budget
abstract: The budget takes up thousands of pages and billions of dollars, and will change the way New Yorkers vote, shop, commute and more. Here is a look at what’s included, what’s not and who is responsible.
lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start your day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline: Mets Rally, Only to Lose to Nationals on Walk-Off Homer
abstract: Trea Turner homered in the third inning off Zack Wheeler and in the ninth off Justin Wilson, salvaging the finale of a three-game series for Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Zack Wheeler, the Mets’ third starter, needed any reminder that his 10-1 record during the second half of last season meant nothing in the new campaign, the Nationals were happy to provide one on Sunday.

headline: The Real Roots of ‘Black Capitalism’
abstract: Nixon’s solution for racial ghettos was tax breaks and incentives, not economic justice.
lead_paragraph: The tax bill President Trump signed into law in 2017 created an “opportunity zones” program, the details of which will soon be finalized. The program will provide tax cuts to investors to spur development in “economically distressed” areas. Republicans and Democrats stretching back to the Nixon administration have tried ideas like this and failed. These failures are well known, but few know the cynical and racist origins of these programs.

headline: Uneasy Steps in Thailand
keywords: ['Elections', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: The country awaits final election results as the military takes the lead.
lead_paragraph: A political party with strong ties to Thailand’s military has garnered the most votes in the recent general election. It was the country’s first ballot since the junta staged a coup in 2014.

headline: Michigan State Heads to Final Four After Banding Together to Shock Duke
abstract: Coach Tom Izzo improved to 2-11 in games against Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski, and the Spartans will advance to a national semifinal against Texas Tech.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cassius Winston held the ball and ran with it as time expired, looking more like an elusive Michigan State running back than a point guard as he evaded all last-second attempts to foul him. The top overall seed, the one with the most dominant freshman in years, was about to fall.

headline: How Blackface Feeds White Supremacy
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sterilization (Reproductive)', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Theater']
abstract: A racist caricature from 19th-century minstrel theater still haunts America.
lead_paragraph: Nineteenth-century minstrel entertainers  spawned a racist caricature that endures to this day when they darkened their faces to portray black people as grinning, dancing simpletons.

abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 1, 2019.

headline: A C.E.O. Who’s Scared for America
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Compensation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Corporations', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Capitalism, he says, is slowly committing suicide.
lead_paragraph: Peter Georgescu — a refugee-turned-C.E.O. who recently celebrated his 80th birthday — feels deeply grateful to his adopted country. He also feels afraid for its future. He is afraid, he says, because the American economy no longer functions well for most citizens. “For the past four decades,” Georgescu has written, “capitalism has been slowly committing suicide.”

headline: Who Should Be Embarrassed?
abstract: If Jussie Smollett’s racists were imaginary, then conservatives can argue the racists we all see are imaginary.
lead_paragraph: “FBI & DOJ to review the outrageous Jussie Smollett case in Chicago. It is an embarrassment to our Nation!” With that tweet, Donald Trump took the absurdity of America’s obsession with a trivial crime and entertainment story and heightened it.
